reviewText:
I never saw anything about this game when it was released. Mostly because of it being released when I was only 9, and at that point in my life I spent my time playing games more aimed at my age range at the time. I saw my brother playing it and thought it would be a really good game to get into the whole Psychological Horror genre. What did I think of it? Well to make sure you don't get confused, I will be breaking this review down into several parts:
The Story.
The Gameplay.
The Dialogue
The Soundtrack.
If it's still good to this day.
If it's worth to buy for it's normal price tag.

The Story:
Although finding it a little unrealistic with it being set in the real world and the overuse of the words 'Darkness' and 'Light' it still grabbed my attention and made me want to keep playing, especially during moments where it was intense. The only real problem I had with the story is a collectible called Manuscript Pages where it basically tells you what is going to happen next or a little later on through the game. This made those moments where it did happen less of a shocker and really ruined that part of the story for me. So much so that I completely stopped reading them when I did pick one up. Overall though the story still got my attention and this was a key element that got me playing till the very end!

The Gameplay:
When I first got introduced to the combat in the game I was really impressed with how unique yet challenging it was. As a means of combat you have to use your torch to make the enemy vulnerable and then finish them with your main weapon. You need bateries to keep your torch charged yet you also need ammo for your gun. Without batteries you can't make the enemy vulnerable to your main weapon, yet without ammo you can't really do anything apart from slow them down. It's a constant battle to keep those two priorities in check. And that I really liked!
However I found that playing on Easy gave me too much ammo due to how easily it was to kill the enemies that I sometimes found myself not really bothering going out looking for ammo drops and hidden secrets that gave me powerful equipment that the game offered. It took almost little to no effort clearing a group of enemies on Easy mode. The only time when I did find myself challenged was when I replayed it on Normal mode.
Though I must admit that having this free time did give me a good chance to find the hidden coffee thermos' and manuscript pages. And boy were they hidden! I took my time in searching and I still haven't found all of them! Along with the achievements, it's gave me a reason to replay and search for the rest.

The Dialogue:
The dialogue was really well done and the voice actors really captured the current situation perfectly! If Alan was mad, the tone of his voice really showed it. If Alan was joking on with another character then the sarcasm and humorus tone really showed as well.

The Soundtrack:
I loved the soundtrack! I can't stress this enough! The songs when you finish an episode were awesome and I loved every second of each and every one of them!

Is it still good to this day?
Although the controls are a little clunky, in short, yes. The gameplay and story more than make up for this draw back and the views during the opening cuscenes were almost breathtaking considering this was an Xbox 360 game to begin with.

Is it worth to buy for it's normal price tag?
As much as this is a good game and all of the really positive points said, if i'm honest? Not really, no. The game is good but if you're a gamer like me that likes to get their money's worth out of games by wasting days on it, this isn't a game you should be considering for a UK price of £22.99 without DLC. ($35.58 for you US players) In my opinion it's a really heavy price tag for a game that could be finished within a day or even a day and a half. This is a game for either the ultimate achievement hunter or if you have nothing to do for the weekend. I'm not saying it's a bad game, it's a really great game and you have my word on it if you're in to these kind of games. I'm saying that I'd rather wait for a really good sale on both the main game and DLC or a heavy price drop.
But if it is on sale? I'd say get it! It's a really unique and awesome game that deserves the love and attention it's getting!

Overall it's an 6.5/10 from me!

reviewText:
Alan Wake ReviewThird person atmospheric horror game with a major flaw.

Alan Wake is a third person atmospheric game from Remedy Entertainment. I will start off by saying that although this game is good, it is certainly overrated by a long milestone. The game really looks like it's going to build up to something. It doesn't. That is the major flaw. The storyline doesn't make sense and the ending is disappointing and confusing. Yes, there is another game in the franchise, Alan Wake's American Nightmare" that takes place a couple of years after the events of this game. But even that game doesn't explain what actually happened.

The game is fun. The shooting is awesome and the mechanics feel really nice. Using a torch as a weapon felt awesome to me. The hidden traps and puddles of darkness were a nice touch. The enemies were never too difficult

reviewText:
Alan Wake Review I bought the Alan Wake Complete pack somewhere around 2011 and 2012, after seeing it at the G4 E3 broadcast and on X-Play, both now extinct. I wanted it so bad, but after seeing it was only for the XBOX, I forgot about it after a while. When I first joined Steam in 2010*, I wanted to buy a game to get full Steam features. After about a year, Sam & Max Seasons 1-3 were on sale, so I bought them. But in the process I saw Alan Wake, which at the moment hadn't sparked any memory of it. For around a year I waited to buy it, and when I saw it was on sale along with Alan Wake's American Nightmare, I had to buy it. Since then it has become and stayed my favorite game of all time, and that's saying something since I've played somewhere around 300-400 games, probably more. I'm going to keep this as un-biased as possible though. There may be spoilers.

Alan Wake
Gameplay and Story
As the story goes, Alan is a famous published author, writer of the Alex Casey novels, who has a severe case of writers block. Alan's wife, Alice Wake, takes Alan on a vacation to Bright Falls, a small town in the Pacific Northwest. Alan and his wife arrive at their lakeside cabin after Alan meets some locals at the Oh-Deer Diner, a cozy small town diner. Alan turns the power on for his wife, who is achluophobic, or has a fear of the dark. Alice calls Alan up to their room, and tells him to check the surprise she left in the study. When Alan opens the door, he finds his typewriter, and that his wife intended for him to come on this trip to get rid of his writers block. Alan get's very angry, and storms out of the cabin. This is where the game's story really starts. The power in the cabin turned off, and Alice screams. Alan yells her name hoping for a reply, and as he walks through the cabin, he finds the door to the dock open, and Alice drowning in the water of Mirror Lake.

The game is played in a third-person view behind Alan. Alan narrates the game, also. There is a small selection of weapons, which consist of a  Colt Python ,  Orion Flare Gun ,  A Over & Under Shotgun ,  Winchester Model 1300 Defender* ,  Remington Model Seven CDL*  , and a  Model 7290 Flashbang Grenade* . The flashbang is sort of like an incinerating bomb to the enemies, called The Taken, which are composed of darkness. Usually you have to shine a flashlight on them to tear away the darkness, then shoot them. But with the flashbang, and the Flare Gun, you can insta-kill them. There are other items such as batteries, flashlights, and flares, which hold the Taken back a certain distance.

Sadly, this game has no other features besides it's linear story mode and achievements. There is another Alan Wake game, Alan Wake's American Nightmare, but it has almost nothing to do with the story and is more of a shooter than a thriller. Remedy Entertainment stated that they have plans for an Alan Wake sequel, but Alan Wake wasn't financally succesful enough to start now, and they are going to finish their upcoming game, Quantum Break, first.

I give this game a  9.5 out of 10  because of the ending, which was fine to an extent. I would recommend this to fiction writers and avid book readers alike.

Thanks for reading this review,

Def

* I lost my other account when I forgot the password and had to make this one, hence the difference between dates on my account of when I made my account. In game the weapons are called Revolver instead of Python, Flare Gun instead of Orion Flare Gun, Shotgun instead of Over & Under Shotgun, Pump-Action Shotgun instead of Winchester Model 1300 Defender, Hunting Rifle instead of Remington Model Seven CDL, and Flashbang instead of Model 7290 Flashbang Grenade.

reviewText:
Alan Wake is one of my all time favorite games.  This thriller is a step up from Quantic Dreams and their games like Heavy Rain and Beyond: Two Souls in the sense of making an enjoyable story whilst keeping the video game experience intact.

The Goods:  The story is incredible with many twists and character development.  The gaming UI is minimalistic yet helpful, and you can turn it off and still enjoy the game (see my guide to know how.)  The variety of enemies keeps the game challenging.  The graphics look good for the time it was made, however the setting of most of the maps has a lot of taxing fog on your machine.  A dodge mechanic is very satisfying to get out of the way of a flying axe.

The Not-So-Goods:  The combat can be a bit repetitiive and overwhelming at times, with many taken ganging up on you.  The game has manuscript pages are taxing to collect and kill the narritive.  While the game has some Story DLC, it seems a bit like an extended universe to compensate for the short yet slow main story experience.

I give this game a 7/10.  The story is incredible, the graphics are good yet taxing, and the AI are a bit lacking in terms of the swarm mechanic they seem to develop, yet the gameplay mechanics cancel it out.

reviewText:
Alan Wake is a masterpiece in every aspect of gaming.

The story is original, exciting and emotional. In my case I couldn't stop playing just because I had to know how Alan Wake's personal hell was going to end.

From gameplay perspective it also has creative innovations combining many different mechanics that we usually don't see in mainstream games. A metric crap-ton of designwork has been put into this game and that can be seen in the credibly done and detailed environment with no invisible walls and such. Graphics are also beautiful and sounds are just fine with excellent lines and voice acting deserving extra praise. It is also a long game, but that's allright because it's all quality. You'd be surprised to know how little boring filling there actually was between the most interesting parts (something we typically see a lot in shooters)

To make a long story short: I wouldn't change any bit of this game. None - And my standards are usually high as Mount Everest.

I wish games like Alan Wake were published more, because this is exactly the way story-driven games should be done. It is solid proof of the fact that game can have amazing story, gameplay, visuals, length and all else in one. It totally deserves all the praise it can be given.
voteText: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This was a hard review to write.

This game is one of my favorite's when it comes to story and voice acting. It's interesting, intense, has an amazing sense of humor, and some of the best side characters of all time. The atmosphere when you begin to find pages is wonderful, as you read about Alan being attacked by an axe murderer just before you're jumped- a classic, but fabulous thriller trick.

However, at the same time, it was one of my least favorites. Though exploration and early level gameplay is entertaining, the level design starts repeating, until you hit the final chapter which is the worst level design I've ever played. There are some gems in the gameplay, such as the Anderson Farm and the Heart of Darkness- but the gameplay of the game suffers enormously from controls that just seem off.

However, as I said before, this story is one that needs to be told. My personal recommendation is to either watch a youtube game movie of it, or to pick up the game if it's on a major sale. You need to hear this story, but you don't need to play the game.

Overall, even with these enormous game flaws, I left the game feeling satisfied- I'd give the game a 6/10, and I'd give the story a 9/10. I wish the developers were given the chance to give this game the sequel it so obviously needs and deserves.

reviewText:
At first I was kind of thinking this would be just another generic horror game, but I found Alan Wake to be a very pleasant surprise indeed. While the gameplay itself is nothing revolutionary, the way the game flows and this game's story is where it really shines.

There is definitely a lot of suspense and mystery in this game and it has its moments of horror as well (albeit its more suprise rather than shock-value horror). Is it an ultra scary/super gory game? No, but its unique narrative and flow don't need it to give you reservations about turning the lights off.

If the game doesn't grab you in the beginning, keep going and give it a bit of time to do so and the game will suck you in. When I first started playing, I almost jumped to the wrong conclusion about the game, but after giving it some time and playing it more and more, it sucked me into it and kept me on the edge of my seat to see what happens next.

Overall, I would say this game is worth the purchase/playthrough and I fully recommend it. Although I can't say that this game has replay value (outside of running achievements and collectables), its definitely worth the initial playthrough.

reviewText:
I'm a chicken when it comes to scary video games, so i was worried that i wouldn't even play this game when i bought it in the steam sales.
At first i disabled the sound and played with music, but after a while i jumped through that fear and had to turn on the sound. I'll explain why.

A very good story, very immersive, that kind of story that keeps you glued to the screen, it's rare these days.

A refreshing gameplay. You'll find a simple flashlight more useful than a shotgun in the game and it has some simple puzzles too. It gets a bit repetitive though. Go from here, to there, now there, now go back, now there again... but the story compensates for it.

The graphics are amazing, period!

The sound fits 100% in this kind of game. You always get the feeling that you really are in the dark and that you will eventually be attacked by surprise.

There are some collectibles you can get. If you get them all in the first playthrough, nice. If you don't, i don't think the game makes much effort for you to play it again and grab them.

7.5/10

reviewText:
Engrossing mystery thriller with unfortunate gameplay weaknesses.

Alan Wake is an immersive experience filled with mystery. Its greatest strength is definitely its plot. It captures its audience by presenting an interesting premise and questions that need answers, which ends up being the main driving force of the game. It did a fantastic job of keeping me interested throughout the game. The story is complemented by (mostly) well written dialogue and some (not all) well constructed characters. The issue I have with the plot is its ending, which contains no real closure or catharsis, which I imagine is due to a possible sequel. Another strength is the atmosphere. The dark tone of the game is achieved by a meticulous attention to lighting and a carefully picked soundtrack. It all blends together to form a dark engrossing mystery.

Unfortunately the gameplay is its greatest weakness. It is thrilling and exciting at first, but quickly turns into a tedious routine that just stops you from exploring the storyline. The formula never changes: shoot the taken" with light
recommended: rinse and repeat. The game does try to add some variety by adding elements of platforming
hoursPlayed: puzzles and even the illusion of exploration. Gameplay is in and of itself not bad. The problem with it is that the gameplay sections are too long. They're so long that whatever fun you had killing the taken dissapates very quickly. This is unfortunate
voteText: because I believe if those sections were made shorter
helpfulPercent: the game would feel a lot more immersive and connected."

reviewText: Imagine if your wife disappears on your vacation,and you keep finding pages of a story you never wrote...that happens in Alan Wake,a best selling writer.The first thing that made me buy this game was the story,and since Remedy Entertainment was working with Rockstar in making of Max Payne,I knew that this game was going to be great.The whole gameplay is awesome.You find batteries which you need to fight of the Taken,which can only be harmed when you destroy their darkness with light,and blow them into pieces.The graphic are very good,and the scenery also great.When I entered a store in town,I bought The Collectors Edition,so I got the soundtrack cd,which is great,a poster,postcards from Bright Falls(the place in the game).For 28 euros,you buy an awesome game,I agree its too much ,but its WORTH IT!

reviewText: Fantastic game. Superb writting is involved (story, characters, events) and the game stands out because of it. Game is organised in episodes and playing feels like watching a good thriller/horror/action tv show, where after watching the episode you just can't wait for next one to begin. This game has some unique mechanics features like using flashlight to fight your opponents and cinematic evading of attacks (something like Bullet Time from Max Payne, but done different).\n\nI will say nothing more (I could spoil something which would be better if you discover it yourself), I'll just say that everything in this game is done with great detail and this is probably one of the best games in its genre, so be sure to check it out.

reviewText:
First, a fair warning to those who suffer from motion sickness: this game may affect you. The FOV is weird, the camera is too quick to react to input and motion is not linear. The worst of all are the driving sequences where all hell breaks loose.

As for the game...
This has to be the most realistic game I've ever played: Alan can't run, Alan can't jump, Alan can't aim, Alan doesn't plan ahead and keeps losing his weapons, Alan is booring, Alan keeps getting into trouble.
Then there's the other side, the unrealistic side where the game keeps spawning enemies just for dificulty sake, where you are punished for exploring, where AI is given an unfair advantage, where you only have the ONE path.
All that make this game very boring and the It's a horror genre game" excuse doesn't cut it.

I was ready to ditch this game by hour 3 but after so many "It get's better later on" comments
date: I've completed the game and I can say: THAT'S A COMPLETE LIE! The game only get's more frustrating as it progresses.\n\nTry the demo to see if you like it first
recommended: but I can't recommen this game. It's just too frustrating

reviewText:
Heavily story driven third person shooter game that plays like some interactive episodic horror series.

Not that scary tho' - often creepy as heck, the forest by night.. But you feel quite empowered with your flashlight and assortment of guns so there's no time for scary moments, just shooting. Those scare jumps? Killed right off the bet. And more enemies at once? Well that sometimes sadly felt more like fighting with controls as opposed to with enemies, so more annoying than scary. Maybe excluding moments when the only recourse was to run to a safe haven, but it was never obvious.

Except near the end of second special episode, now there's a scary part.

I realized how dependant have I become on minimaps, getting lost in the woods. But in the end indicator where to go is really all you need, except if you want to wander around for hidden bonuses, then it's time to actually pay attention to your surroundings not to get lost.

But story, story, it's really great. Exceptionally meta.

reviewText:
I always loved the masters of horror and suspense, H.P. Lovecraft, Stephen King, Alfred Hitchcock, Edgar Alan Poe,...
And when I first heard about Alan Wake I got instantly attracted to the game. A story about a writer, who lost his wife, and now trying not just to get her back, but also trying to stop a dark force from being unleashed in the world maybe sound cliche, but the way they make this story really captures you into finishing it.
The gameplay is fun and easy to learn, but not too easy, and rewards exploration with collectables (missing pages, radios, TVs, thermals, pyramids of cans to shoot, and also ammo and weapons).
The combat can get a bit repetitive (see an enemy, flash him with your lantern, shoot him until he dies and repeat with the next enemy), but for me it didn't ruined the fun of the game.

So yeah, if you like survival horror with a good story, buy this game.

reviewText:
Highly recommended, as long as you have a controller. The first few times I gave this game a shot, I insisted on using the mouse and keyboard, but the more you play, the more you realize the combat moments in this game aren't about precision, but more about crowd control. The story itself is highly original, which I don't want to delve too much into for fear of spoiling part of the adventure. What I will say is that, since the game is broken up into episodes with distinct ending points, and each episode taking about 2 hours to complete, it gives you some very easy moments to stop and return to the game later.

The graphics still hold up incredibly well, the sound design is phenomenal, the voice acting does a great job of making you long to hear more, or occasionally sending chills down your spine as you run through a dark forrest, listening to the constant dark presence approaching behind you, with enemies snarling sinister sounding dialogue and chasing you down with the sole intent to kill you.

Worth a buy, I definitely had a lot of fun with this one. AND it includes the two DLC episodes that were released on 360 for free!

reviewText:
This game has really surprised me.

I recieved it as a gift shortly before Christmas, and waited a while to play it.  My Fiance watched me play the first scene or two.  She then demanded that I was not allowed to play the game if she wasn't here - because she LOVED watching it.

And I did too -  just as much as I loved playing it.  It unfolds like an awesome movie - but with more detail than a movie... more like an awesome book.  Which fits the bill perfectly, since you're playing an Author.

Maybe as an Author myself (ask me about my blogs!) this game touched base with me more easily than it would others, but I would still recommend it to anyone.  The flashlight + pistol gameplay feels different than any other game I've ever played.  The enemies are actually scary, and when you need to get away from one in a hurry, the situation will leave your palms sweating.

10/10. Very suspenseful game that is both a joy to play and a joy to watch / listen to. Excellent writing.  This game deserves so many more accolades than it has recieved, and I honestly feel like you'd be missing out on one of the most unique game experiences you'll ever have if you pass this game up.  Buy it now.

reviewText:
Atmosphere... it's just great.
It sucks you in right away. It feels like you're really in a horror story and you feel the tension almost all the time. Listening to a radio show or a TV show or when there is a day outside is like a moments of relief. Never thought a flashlight could be your greatest weapon... well, except for flashbang grenades, which, i think, are little overpowered, because you can kill almost every taken in your sight with one grenade. And those grenades aren't very rare.
Last mission felt a bit too long and shallow - just fighting your way trough hordes of taken and angry cars, boats and other trash.
Definitely will play one more time on nightmare difficulty to collect all the manuscript pages and other collectibles that aren't available on easier difficulties.
Great and, in my opinion, unique game - 9/10

reviewText:
The vast and beautiful scenery in Alan Wake often gives the impression that the game is bigger than it is. I was, therefore, unsurprised to learn that the game was originally envisioned as being more of a free-roaming RPG before the limitations of the Xbox turned it into a a more liner 'on-rails' effort. And it shows. The landscape begs to be explored, but as soon as you travel any distance off the predetermined track you come to a cliff face or edge, and you start to feel a bit penned-in.
The driving sections offer more of a sense of freedom, but even then you've got to stick to the road if you want to advance the plot.
The story itself is interesting, and wears its Twilight Zone/Stephen King inspirations on its sleeve, but it has trouble captivating because from the very start you don't know what's real and what's a dream, which makes the threat feel too ethereal rather than something solid that can hurt you (even though it obviously can). You find yourself constantly wondering, 'is this bit a dream or real?', 'am I alive or dead?', 'do I really care?'.
The atmosphere is the game's strongest point, and makes you wonder why more horror/suspense games don't do it better (I'm looking at you, Resident Evil series). The use of the flashlight is original, and the combat well executed, although it does suffer from being a tad repetitive by the game's end.
It's a shame so much of the game is set at night (something necessary to the plot), because the graphics are showcased much better in the daylight scenes, and I'd have quite happily spent hours roaming around the hills and valleys of Bright Falls if given the opportunity.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game. I love the plot in this game, and I love the writing in this game.

This baby uses it's chapters like episodes to a television series, giving you a recap of what happened, and a preview of what's to come. The combat allows you to evade if you get surrounded, so you always have the option to escape or fight (except specific times where you have to take everything down to advance for story reasons).

I can't recommend this game enough. If you don't particularly care for games that try to creep you out with horror elements, rest assured that this isn't your gore-filled schlock that is churned out every year as a remix of the same thing - this is Alan Wake, and what you get is story. Ambient noise, suspense, and a non-reliance on jump scares is what make this game great - you are a writer trapped in a story, and it is an experience.

reviewText: Alan Wake is one of pleasant surprises when it comes to games i've played this year. You start off as a book writer, not a commando or spy or anyone related in military in that matter, that got cought in a nightmare. It starts off with Alan driving through a dark road and hitting someone with a car. When Alan checked who did he hit he saw nothing. But after he started to walk on foot the mysterious character from his one of his written books started to chase him. Few minutes later you learn that the everything is covered in shadows and the only way to harm your enemies is to aim your flashlight directly to your foe and remove armor of shadow for him to become vulnarable. It's pretty interesting mechanic but it gets tedious after a while. The story  once reference Stephen King novels and I figured it might have been huge influence making the game since in some ways it feels like playing S.K. novel.\nGameplay is pretty weak in this game. Limited weaponry, driving sections are worst part of the game. However if you go search for secret documents which are scattered through levels, you get better immersion.\nSo even tho game had some mechanics i didn't enjoy it's still pretty decent game. 6.5/10

reviewText:
Let me start by saying that this is a Really good story based game. I'll begin with the pros being that the game offers a lot of areas to search while keeping on track with the story. I enjoyed looking for collectibles and hidden Extra items! The enemies of the game can be difficult at times, if you don't know how to eliminate them. I played the game on normal and still had some trouble killing/escaping the enemies. Another thing which I have to mention is all the smooth cutscenes between point a and b while doing the story mode. This game definitely made me jump from some enemy popping up behind a door! This game offers various story episodes and I say this because after each episode you get a nice preview of what happened in the previous episode! In a way this game is very unique because of all the types of enemies you fight and the weapons you use Ex. You don't use snipers or grenades but instead a flashlight and a revolver/shotgun/riffle! Also you can access free extra downloadable content for the game itself. I liked in a certain place in the game there was a Q.R. code and I scanned it and it led to a picture (Scan it yourself to find out ;D).  Another thing I would like to
mention is that the game fits it's price for what it Offers:

-> Many hours of gameplay
-> Different difficulty's
-> An intriguing story
-> Various enemies starting from a taken" to flying items (The main enemies are called "the Taken")
Now every game has some cons
date:
but for this game I didn't notice all that many... There were some and I'm going to list them below

-> Areas where you would get stuck between a rock or a log
-> A.I. getting stuck in place
-> During cutscenes glitchy item picking

These are the only ones I could think of because as I mentioned above the game is very amazing!
I rate this game a 9/10
recommended: I don't rate it a 10 because of the few cons listed above. I recommend this game to anyone who wishes to get involved in a story mode/ thriller game!"

reviewText:
Intro & SummaryRemedy Entertainment (Alan Wakes' developers) have a varied history on different platformers and a solid background of really polished, clean cut games with a more interesting take or angle than you'd expect from an AAA title. To me, Remedy Entertainment produce games that are like the interesting B-Side of the hit Pop record, and that's what Alan Wake is: Weirder and more interesting than the Triple A's, but with all the polish and production value you'd expect of one.

HighlightsSuspenseful collectibles and foreshadowing are layered around a very detailed world to produce some startling moments and encounters.

* A newer angle on combat and some survival elements which the world is built to fit around
* Some very interesting detail and things to uncover in the world when hunted for
* Very polished, feels like an AAA production

MistakesAlan Wake is often called Stephen King: The Game, which is meant as a good thing. Interestingly though, it suffers from the same problems as Stephen King novels and movie adaptations; almost silly story elements and inexplicable character motivations. Otherwise, on the whole, it's polished enough that it never lets you down in any one area.

* Far too easy, a real lack of challenge
* No variety of enemies

RecommendationsGameplay comes in at a strong 11-14 hours play time and while it doesn't have much re-playability, it's a collector/achievement hunters dream. It's available on Steam at between £22.99/$29.99 and £29.99/$39.99 which, for a 4 year+ old game is simply overpriced. Fortunately it goes on sale very often for -80% and even comes up in Indie Bundles from time to time.

* The DLC is a waste of time. Instead, you can find the Developer Commentaries on YouTube here https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Db7-3c1kh_w and the Soundtrack on Spotify here https://open.spotify.com/album/0sfJBWav58STfyxS9F08xt
* ROW copies are cheapest from Japan.

reviewText:
I had never played Alan Wake before and after seeing it on sale during the 2014 Summer Sale I decided to invest in it. This is by far one of the greatest storylines of any PC game that I have played; the detail, concept, graphics and soundtrack compliment the plot to make it one true masterpiece. Once I had downloaded and installed the game I adjusted my settings and went in game, the twelve hours I have on this game are from me playing this game back-to-back in a single day, the second best purchase of any game in my extensive Steam library; I can't recommend this game highly enough.


Pros:
A very well optimised game, I was well below the minimum requirements and still achieved a solid 30-45FPS on low settings.

Captivating and perplex storyline that made me play the game from start to finish in a single day.

Amazing graphics even on low settings, after seeing it running on ultra at 4K resolution, it looks even more amazing.

After purchasing this game I recieved a free 320KBs MP3 copy of the soundtrack and it's absolutely astounding, the composer is to be congratulated.Cons:
A sequel was made (Alan Wake's American Nightmare), but it felt more of a technical demonstration and failed to captivate me in the same way this game did.

reviewText:
Intro & SummaryRemedy Entertainment (Alan Wakes' developers) have a varied history on different platformers and a solid background of really polished, clean cut games with a more interesting take or angle than you'd expect from an AAA title. To me, Remedy Entertainment produce games that are like the interesting B-Side of the hit Pop record, and that's what Alan Wake is: Weirder and more interesting than the Triple A's, but with all the polish and production value you'd expect of one.

HighlightsSuspenseful collectibles and foreshadowing are layered around a very detailed world to produce some startling moments and encounters.

* A newer angle on combat and some survival elements which the world is built to fit around
* Some very interesting detail and things to uncover in the world when hunted for
* Very polished, feels like an AAA production

MistakesAlan Wake is often called Stephen King: The Game, which is meant as a good thing. Interestingly though, it suffers from the same problems as Stephen King novels and movie adaptations; almost silly story elements and inexplicable character motivations. Otherwise, on the whole, it's polished enough that it never lets you down in any one area.

* Far too easy, a real lack of challenge
* No variety of enemies

RecommendationsGameplay comes in at a strong 11-14 hours play time and while it doesn't have much re-playability, it's a collector/achievement hunters dream. It's available on Steam at between £22.99/$29.99 and £29.99/$39.99 which, for a 4 year+ old game is simply overpriced. Fortunately it goes on sale very often for -80% and even comes up in Indie Bundles from time to time.

* The DLC is a waste of time. Instead, you can find the Developer Commentaries on YouTube here https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Db7-3c1kh_w and the Soundtrack on Spotify here https://open.spotify.com/album/0sfJBWav58STfyxS9F08xt
* ROW copies are cheapest from Japan.

reviewText:
This game is an underated gem in the survial horror genre

You play as Alan Wake, a writter looking for his missing wife in a sleepy woodland town thats being taken over by living darkness.

What this game does best is presentaion and atmosphere.  The levels are gorgeous during the day and spooky during the night and you'll find your self jumping at shadows and curising the sound of the wind.  The story is presented as if you were in a living book with Alan narrating the events and objectives as you play.  Things start to get really intresting when you begin finding pages to a manuscript that you have no memory writing and that describe things you have no way of know or even things that have yet to occur.  Top that off with amazing sound design and a kick ♥♥♥ soundtrack and i've never been so emersed in a game before.

The games main short coming is combat.  To kill enemies you have to shine a flashlight on them until they become vunerable before shooting them. and thats it.  And theres only about 4 or 5 enemy types in the whole game so combat becomes samey real fast.  they do try to mix things up every now and then by throwing you into ambushes where you have to fend of multipule waves of enemies at a disadvatge or giving you a driving segmant here and there.  At least the controls are solid so combat doesn't feel frustrating.

There are also little hidden story elements and item cashes hidden through out the enviroments like radio boradcasts or episodes of a strange show similar to outer limits or twilight zone. this adds a bit of exploration to the leves and gives at least a little replay value.

This isn't a perfect game but its one that you really should play if you want a solid story and great atomsphere.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
RECOMENDED FOR THE STORY-DRIVEN PLAYER

Alan Wake is an action/light horror thriller that tells the story of the aforementioned guy (Alan Wake). He's the writer of a single book that was apparently SO appealing to his wife that she...kinda made him take a vacation for the hidden purpose of getting more material out of him. I don't want to say too much, but the thing that stands out to me the MOST in this game is the story and the gameplay.
The enemies in the game--from what I've played thus far--are characters from the very story he created, and they're all more that hell bent on killing him. Actually, I'm pretty sure that the entire game is going to be the one in the book he wrote, and this becomes evident really early on in the game, as you find scriptures of pages of words hidden in the environment.

The combat primarilly revolves around you blincing these enemies with a very powerful flashlight (Seriously, these are ENERGIZER batteries and they last for ♥♥♥♥). You can shine it at them and start to break the blankets of darkness that protect them, or you can go literal energizer mode and shine an intense beam of light at them, holding them in place and doing MAJOR damage to their shields, breaking them faster and allowing you to finish them off with your bullets (you have a gun, too, don't worry. Your flashlight isn't some crazy contraction. Also, it gets rather difficult at times to do this, because you're often outnumbered, and your enemies are very fast; just as fast as you at times.

They WERE going to make Alan Wake 2, which looked SOOOOOO COOL, but I dunno. Guess Remedy's putting their newer ideas in Quantum Break instead D: It's fine, though :D

10/10, though I don't have many pet peeves about games ^3^

reviewText: Great action adventure with a fantastic story! The story alone is what kept me playing for 15 hours. The visuals and audio were beautiful, and the presentation of the content in a movie-like fashion was brilliant and fit the game perfectly. The NPCs in the game are VERY well done and helped lighten the mood in a dark game. Not to mention, I don't think I ever heard a repeated phrase by a character and I loved that about this game.\n\nThe actual game play however was very poorly done for my taste. The fights were repetitive, predictable, intrusive, and unnecessary. Every 15 steps the game would interrupt my progression with a slow-motion introduction of a new" set of enemies
date: and all I could think was "just let me play the game". It made enemies too familiar which took away any of the horror feel that they were supposed to bring to the game.\n\nThere were a few pieces of actual game play that were fantastic and stood out from the rest in my eyes. The battle on the stage at the farm was the most enjoyable out of all of the combat scenes in the game. The music and the rock-and-roll stage scene made me feel like a boss killing all of the Taken
recommended: and having Barry there to cheer me on made it feel like I was fighting with a friend. Although not every combat scene can feel that epic
hoursPlayed: having more scenarios like this would have made the game play much more enjoyable. Even just changing up the music for other fights would have helped add variety.\n\nWhile I did not enjoy the combat
voteText: every other aspect of the game greatly helped it redeem itself. The entire story and ending left me in awe and I very much look forward to seeing it continue in the future. Definitely recommend this to anyone who loves a good story and an overall beautiful game."

reviewText:
Alan Wake had a huge name before I even knew what it was about. Rumours and small spoils motivated me to play it for myself. On 1 May 2015 I finally set out on this adventure as a well known, cocky, used book writer who went on a retreat to Bright Falls in Washington, USA. It sets off on a slow pace and introduces you to all basic concepts and details.

The main goal of Alan Wake was to create an immersive movie or story with little effort needed from the viewer, they achieved this with simple controls and an easy difficulty to play on. Do not be fooled and think that the entire story is all fun and games, at the end of each episode everything would get intense, hordes of taken would appear leaving you to fight or flee for your life.

Categorised as a thriller I back the entire game, dwelling in silence with illuminating glare from the moon evolves slowly into a suspenseful walk with atmospheric music setting the tone of every scene. Even the classic jump scares are included, strolling through a home when suddenly a taken busts through the door charging you with al there is. Some were predictable and some were not, but balanced and not worn out.

Physical gameplay felt unnatural and sloppy but to be fair it was a conversion form Xbox to PC. Minor glitches like getting stuck on something or jumping and getting stuck but no big problems.

Graphics….. This was hard, reviewing in 2015 vs back in 2010 is quite a difference seeing that my GTX 760 made mincemeat of any graphical requirement it threw my way. Certain unpleasantness struck me in cinematics due to visible comers and edges, Alan’s Face his hands ect.
BUT
Comparing to other titles released in 2010 it seems like the quality of visuals were up to standard, titles like Mass Effect 2, Just Cause 2, Assassin’s creed Brotherhood also had some of these characteristics that feels unpleasant to the eyes.

This story was amazing and immersive…

At first they make you compare yourself to Alan, at this stage you would feel all his pain. Then they drop an unravelling bomb on you where you start to hate our Hero, after a while you start agreeing again and feel his drive, anger, hatred and determination to finish his adventure.

At the very end the unthinkable happens and they leave you on the biggest cliff-hanger ever created by mankind.
They later on released special episodes 1 and 2 which continues the story after the story, these were not as good as the main story but also deserves your attention.  It does not really enlighten you about happenings after and if you can shut off your entire brain and only receive entertainment through playing games, I would implore you to do this as the FINAL
did not give any closure and generated more hope than was needed.

Unfortunately it seems that Alan Wake 2 will not make an appearance in the future, Quantum break releasing exclusively to Xbox one will receive this title. Producers and directors feel that it is not within the age or time to make a new Title to this extremely awesome piece of art and creative immersion.

My next game would be Alan Wakes American Nightmare.

Hit the review section up to see may say in a months’ time.

FINAL VERDICT: ABSOLUTE YES, Add it to your rich-story category in your library.

reviewText:
A severely underrated game in every respect.

I had initially purchased the game on the 360 when it was still an exclusive and spent hours upon hours playing and replaying the game. The rich and detailed world, and the startling and beautiful atmosphere left me wanting more at every turn. This game is the prophetic flagship of storytelling in video games - and should set the gold standard as time moves on.

The gameplay is simple, fast paced and tense - adrenaline fueled, sometimes challenging and always fair. The story will keep you invested long after you lean back idly in your chair to contemplate the unfolding narrative, and the dramatic set-pieces tie the game together into a beautiful package you'd regret missing.

The soundtrack is a pure, undisputed work of art, and is included should you pick up the collector's edition extras; worth every penny.

You should be playing this game right now.

reviewText:
Alan Wake id undoubtedly a triple-A game and there's no questioning in it being a GOOD GAME. After playing for several hours and not completing it, there's one thing I need to point out: the. story. is. killer.

In all due seriousness, however, Alan Wake is a writer to have found himself in a messy situation when Mr. Wake and his wife just wanted to go relaxing outside of the city. His wife goes missing and he needs to figure stuff out. It all gets way more complicated than that, and it makes you scratch your head at times. Overall, the story makes you feel; that's what makes a good story!

And the environment certainly adds to it. Whoever designed the levels need to be glorified. They did a stellar work designing/creating levels that makes you fear the night (literally fear it) and adore the day. During the daytime, you're found in a 1960-style small town that really makes you just want to grab a chair, sit down and relax. It's so calm and beautiful. But then comes the night, and Alan needs to fight for his life and so do you.

Speaking of fighting for his life, you get extraordinarily limited attempting to do that very task. There's a ridiculous limit on the ammunition you can carry (despite ammunition being found everywhere, it does run out quickly) that makes it incredibly difficult to get out of a hairy situation. For example, if you get stuck and there's no ammo around & you meet a ton of enemies, well, tough luck.. your best bet is to run away from them.. in other words, no combat action. CHEAP AND UNACCEPTABLE ♥♥♥♥ING SOLUTION". But
date: usually you do have ammo if you use your equipment very conservatively.. no fun doing that

reviewText:
Alan wake is another classic and well done story written by one of my favourites, Sam Lake.

Without actually looking into the story prior to playing the game you will be absolutely blown away!

The combat system is suitable for the type of game it is trying to be, and at times it adds quite a large amount of difficulty whilst up against larger amounts of enemies. Even on the normal difficulty you will find yourself trying to avoid alot of battles due to the fact of having limited ammo/battery supplies, however the game still balances this out with environmental advantages.

A lot of other reviewers have tried to class this game as a typical shooter genre"
date: but i find this to not be the case. Though it does have some minor auto healing abilities the combat itself is quite unique and far from a typical shooter. To be honest a majority of the time you'd prefer to use enviromental light or obstacles to defeat enemies as opposed to your weapons.\n\nDefinately in my list of all time favourites
recommended: right with another Sam Lake written game "Max Payne". Well done Remedy!"

reviewText:
What a game! Alan Wake plays like Stephen King meets Max Payne, meets Twin Peaks and The Twilight Zone, meets a mix of zombie and vampire movies!

Remedy did it again, the game felt quite like Max Payne did, while at the same time managing to set its own distinctive path.

The atmosphere, story and graphics were awesome, like a good Stephen King horror book/movie should be. The creators made it so the game plays in episodic segments, much like a TV series and the inspirations they got from said movies, tv shows and books are noticeable throughout all its length.

I personally found it to be much more than a horror story though, it also has the classic struggle of a man to save his loved one, but even more than that, it's a metaphor for a man who tries to overcome his fears and problems and in the end manages to return". I won't spoiler you the rest

reviewText:
What can I say about Alan Wake? Its an interesting game by the guys who did Max Payne, and it shows; Alan Wake is a story focused action thriller, much like Max Payne, but instead of being a neo-noir crime thriller set in New York City, Alan Wake is a supernatural thriller (though some people might call it horror, i'm a little hesitant to call it such, since it's not really scary) set in the fictional town of Bright Falls, Washington. Though it does have some shortcomings, ultimately, Alan Wake is a engrossing piece of fiction which does it's best to recapture the cinematic storytelling of Max Payne, and for the most part, it delivers.

The game is visually impressive, with lighting being both stunning and a key part of the gameplay, and models being fairly well detailed. The shadowy particle effects when the enemies show up is neat, and overall the game exudes atmostphere. The musical score is decent, though utimately forgettable.

Gameplay is probably the weakest aspect of Alan Wake, but it's still suprisingly solid. It has your standard set of third person controls, but what it adds is it's light mechanic. Enemies in the game cannot be killed unless they are weakened by light first. This can be from your torch (flashlight), a flare gun, or really any light source lying around. Enemies won't attack you under street lamps for instance, though often, to continue, you have to go out into the darkness and fight the enemies. there are some puzzley section in the game, but they aren't too difficult to figure out, but it's worth mentioning.

Where Alan Wake really shines is in it's narrative, but moreso how it tells this narrative. While at first narrration by a Stephen King-esque character seems like it wouldn't be quite so interesting, the delivery is great. When things start to go wrong in Bright Falls, the atmosphere compliments the narratation. It works quite well, and in additon, splitting up the game into segmented chapters also adds to the Twin Peaks feel to the game. The story has plenty of twists and turns, and the dialogue is written well enough to keep you engaged. While the ending is somewhat dissapointing, Alan Wake's story (moreso it's storytelling) is excellent and will keep you engrossed until the end.

If you like narrative driven games, or you like supernatural thrillers reminiscent of Stephen King or Twin Peaks, Alan Wake is definitely a recommendation.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This game is fantastic! I know many will go into expecting something like Silent Hill or other franchise survival-horror games but this is something completely different.  Alan Wake offers atmosphere and likeable characters over dense mechanics and the most fun you will have in this game is standing and listening to the radio, thinking about what has transpired and what it all means.  Though they are simplistic, the mechanics are very intuative and fun and keep the story moving forward which is crucial.  There are even moments where the mechanics are used in very intricate ways and create a very balanced feel to all the missions.  Alan Wake as a protangonist is goofy but I feel that the campy attitude only serves to tell a more compelling story and ultimately makes the game more fun over scary.  Highly recommended!

I compare the game itself to a music album which after the first listen doesn't blow you away but over time becomes one of your favorites without even realizing it.\n\nAlan Wake has many unique characteristics to it but yet stays familiar with the controls and 3rd person shooter concept.  The story grips you from the beginning and constantly unfolds before you but leaves you still thinking "Um

The gameplay surrounding the darkness and Alan Wake's companion the light gives you a bleak and desperate feeling through out even when you have the comfort of friends (and very capable ones) to help you through.\n\nWake is stuck in his own nightmare and quickly finds out he has already written it.  He follows the trail that leads him to the darkness.  The question which you must answer is if Alan will defeat the darkness

reviewText: Alan Wake is AWESOME. Its story is so damn intense, you just can't stop playing (obviously given that you like the psycho-horror thriller genre). The strange TV series-like subdivision in Episodes instead of standard game chapters is actually quite refreshing in my opinion. The graphics are top notch, as well as the gameplay (even though the shooting parts can be a bit repetitive sometimes, but that doesn't disturb me very much actually... it is compensated by some lovely interesting physics puzzles; reminds me a bit of the good old HL2 style), but I can't point out enough HOW MUCH I love the story of this game. It really is its strongest point, and I simply love it. You should definitively buy this game if you like action/horror games with an intense and very deep (horror)story.\nAnd the soundtrack? Never mind that.... gives me goosebumps EVERY time I play it! Just AWESOME. Go play it now if you haven't already!

reviewText:
I especially  liked the combat, while simple, works well for the game and keeps the survival feeling. I never got tired of it either, whenever you get that barely made stumbling dodge you breathe a sigh of relief as you have a few precious moments to regain composure. The darkness will take you if you're not aware at all times, but luckily enough it's also not unfair about it. You'll also learn to love flares, which are just very fun to pop when you're surrounded as the combat can get very cinematic. (without any hitch ups in my experience)

The entire experience is a wonderful one, between the music, the visuals, the narrative and the plot, it's a great experience. And it never falls into typical horror story sillyness, yes things will jump out at you, but the real danger is because the darkness itself is something that cannot be fought directly. Alan can slow it down all he likes, but it'll take a lot more than a torch and a revolver to end it. And that feeling sticks with you, you can fend off the darkness, but beating it? Now that's a whole different story...

reviewText: Alan Wake, still the best flashlight game ever made. More non-rechargeable batteries are used here than at toys-r-us.  It's about a man, his flashlight, a wooded area of North America, lots of wind and guys trying to kill you with axes.  Basically, we are talking about your typical skiing vacation. I like the cut-scenes, that's when the developer goes the extra mile to make the graphics work.  But in this game, the character facial movements resemble a bad Hollywood botox treatment repeated 1000 times.  The attempt to match words with lips is definitely an alien concept.  (Please don't tell the developers and hurt their feelings. They are very very sensitive and I hear them crying right now.)  I really don't know what I am trying to communicate here. But there's a cool looking babe walking there across the street! Can you tell that I am typing my own introspective thinking? Yeah, it's boring. Sorry. Hope this review helped you decide something.

The gameplay can be a little awkward, although I am sure that is just my stubby finers combined with panic induced key bashing. The storyline will keep you hooked and this is genuinely a game I could not stop playing. reviewText:
A Review Mostly for me so I know I’ve completed the story, as well as feedback on the game.

My Thoughts:- a nice cool game enjoyed it a lot, Bit confused to where the American nightmare fits in with this? I did run into a few graphic’s problems with the grass being blocky like 2D.

Achievements:- 37 of 67 (55%) Achievements Earned

Graphics:- looks very nice on a decent system at full blast but I did run into some bad grass textures at some parts in the game.

Game Play:- best played in the dark, on your own, may want to get the feel of the controls beforehand as I had to readjust every now and then the sensitivity

Story:- You are alan wake a writer oh holiday with your wife alice, but something old and dark has forced you to write a story in exchange for your wife.

Replayability:- the games got plenty of achievement’s 67 and 3 modes of play easy, normal and nightmare.

What Could Be Added: nothing much performance boost or fix the crapy grass textures

Rating:- 8 / 10

reviewText:
A thriller action adventure that plays with light and darkness. You take the role of Alan Wake, a writer, who goes on a vacation with his wife. Too bad their cottage (or the lake around it) is haunted and the darkness takes his wife hostage. Alan hits his head and is confused, alarmed and out-right horrified to find himself attacked by shadowy but unearthly shapes of townsfolk, friends and enemies alike. To survive he has to use light and gunmanship.

Basically Alan meets a number of horrors along the way and beats most of them with elaborate use of light, guns and fast feet. Story advances smoothly along six chapters, each of which brings new kinds of enemies, tools and of course lore and insight into the destiny of Alan.

After enjoying the story once you can play it through on a higher difficulty level, dubbed Nightmare, with stronger enemies and due to that scarcer resources. There are also two bonus chapters that are situated after the main story. The whole game takes anything from 15 to 25 hours to play through, more if you play it through with the higher difficulty level and even more if you go looking for all the extra stuff that gives you achievements. The main attraction however, at least to me, was the story that is enhanced by the immersion provided by believable body language and good voice acting.

Get it for full price and you probably won't regret it anyway, but the game is frequently on a high discount that gets you a nice thrilling story with a price of a large soda.

reviewText: Like playing a Stephen King novel. And I did get a little tired of Alan Wake's complete lack of fitness as I struggled to sprint more than 50 meters when running away from the shadowy nasties. The gameplay isn't overly complex which isn't a bad thing as it allows to concentrate more on what is going on.\n\nAlan Wake is an adventure game with strong elements of action and horror and highly recommended for anyone who wants to play through a good story.

reviewText:
Игра с отличным закрученным сюжетом. Всем советую поиграть!
Сюжет игры повествует о приключениях писателя Алана Уэйка, автора бестселлеров в жанре «триллера», оказавшегося в городе Брайт-Фоллс, штата Вашингтон, где оживают персонажи и события его произведений. Пытаясь разобраться в происходящем и выяснить, что случилось с его женой, Алан узнаёт много неожиданного о маленьком городке — раньше здесь жил писатель Томас Зэйн. Его жена погибла, утонув при странных обстоятельствах в озере, рядом с которым они жили, хотя она и была прекрасной пловчихой. Зэйн, ныряющий на дно озера, в один прекрасный день обнаруживает там некую плывущую чёрную массу, с которой заключает сделку. Сделка состояла в том, что Зэйн пишет рассказ, и высвобождает Тёмную Сущность со дна озера. Она же в свою очередь воскрешает его жену — Барбару Джаггер.
Барбара ожила, но это была лишь человеческая оболочка, заполненная Тёмной Сущностью. Томас осознаёт свою ошибку и вырезает Барбаре сердце, пытаясь уничтожить освобождённое им зло. Но это не останавливает Тёмную Сущность, Барбара по прежнему жива, и тогда он уходит вместе с ней под воду, но так и не достигает дна. А остров с домом исчезли, оставив жителей с новостью об ожившем вулкане под озером в 70-е. Призванный пером Алана, он приходит к нему на помощь и на краткий миг ослабляет Тёмную Сущность. Воспользовавшись этим, Уэйк в ужасе убегает из домика на острове, разбивается на машине, но выживает. Теперь ему придётся пройти сквозь океан ужаса и безумия, выжигая себе путь фонариком и встречая злобных тварей, от захваченного Тёмной Сущностью охотника и сошедших с ума федералов до завораживающего сердце торнадо.
Кому лень это читать: http://ru.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alan_Wake#.D0.A1.D1.8E.D0.B6.D0.B5.D1.82

reviewText: Alan Wake features an extremely entertaining and engrossing storyline complete with gorgeous visuals, a fantastic soundtrack, and fluent (optimized), mechanics. The game throws you into the middle of a familiar, yet unknown landscape (level design is excellent!), where you are forced to survive the onslaught of darkness and insanity with naught but a flashlight and pistol, all the while trying to figure out the cause and consequence of the characters actions through self narration via manuscripts you find throughout the journey. Alan Wake was a pleasant surprise in both quality and enjoyment, and comes recommended highly!

reviewText: Alan Wake comes to the PC and brings his paranormal curse with him, completely intact. The same defining horror experience is here, occasionally marred by outdated graphics and quirky character animation, but everything else works like a charm.Alan Wake is not a flawless game. The combat system is entertaining at first but its magic is killed by unnecessary and numerous action segments. Still the game is a very atmospheric adventure of a very rare kind.The mix between intriguing storytelling and near-perfect game design elevates Alan Wake to an extraordinarily finely crafted experience. Even if  you will shelf it after completing and never take it out again: This one playthrough will be a lasting experience. Alan Wake is something special that enriches the world of gaming.

reviewText:
Alan Wake follows the story of the best-selling thriller novelist Alan Wake, as he tries to uncover the mystery behind his wife's disappearance during a vacation while the events of his latest novel come to life.
This game has a similar structure to any TV Series, divided by episodes full of plot twists.
The story is complex and intriguing, the combat system is great, the graphics are pretty good and the atmosphere is just extraordinary.
I highly recommend Alan Wake as one of the best horror experiences in videogaming.

reviewText:
A richly detailed environment, in lightness and darkness, bring this game very much to life. Atmospheric surroundings and sound effects, embellished by excellent cut-scenes that help the narrative as the story unfolds.
The plot is fantastic yet grounded at the same time, riddled with clever what-ifs and many-layered implications of what it means to write creatively and what it is to truly push the boundaries between imagination and reality in this process.
The gameplay itself is pretty damn epic as well. Action remains fast-paced and challenging without being too frustrating, supplies such as ammo or batteries are plentiful enough to stop you ever running the risk of being completely defenceless while remaining sparse enough to keep you considering what to preserve and when, and there is a varying degree of weaponry and enemy strength and speed to keep it interesting.
One thing I really like about this game is that the game never gives you too much ammo, so you never really have that safe feeling when you are trudging through the woods. In other games you usually stack up on a lot of guns and ammo and end up being a one man army - not so in Alan Wake. Here, your character really is a frail writer with a flashlight and a tweed jacket, not a super soldier - your most powerful weapon is also the light. Without light, even the most potent gun cannot so much as even scratch the enemy.

reviewText: Alan Wake features an extremely entertaining and engrossing storyline complete with gorgeous visuals, a fantastic soundtrack, and fluent (optimized), mechanics. reviewText:
Classic but underrated horror adventure
This is a very good game indeed. It does a marvellous job in telling a convincing story, and it gives you the felling to be part of a unique setting. This is not done by a large amount of cutscenes or - worse - voice-overs, no: the game manages to give you the feeling to be the protagonist in a good, and scary, movie. Everything in this game is polished to - almost - perfection, but most impressive is the way in which Alan Wake succeeds in drawing you into the story and the setting. After sometime, you feel like being Alan Wake, and like living his story.

reviewText:
I played through Alan Wake a year or so ago based on the recommendations of some friends. It turned out to be a fantastic survival horror type game that really centers on the story. If you’ve played the Max Payne games you’ll have a good idea of how the game story I presented. It’s almost like an interactive movie, making the first playthrough great, but might cut down the replay value (because you already know what happens).

Spoilers ahead
You play the title character Alan Wake, a horror writer visiting a small town with his wife to get some rest & relaxation. After you reach your cabin in the woods, strange things start happening. Your wife disappears and the world is cast in darkness. Think Silent Hill, but instead of a “Hell World” it’s like night with swirling shadows all over. You eventually get pursued by law enforcement including a crazy FBI agent who seems to really hate you for some reason. All the while as you move through the world, you find glowing typewritten pages that are kind of like a book that you’re living (the pages are out of order though, so you don’t know what’s going to happen next). It turns out later that you’re living out a novel that you’ve forgotten writing and an evil force is trying to get you to write it in a certain way (so the evil force wins). Throughout the game there is voice over narration (by your character) that does a good job laying things out as well as describing the confusion that will probably be going through your mind.

The game is played as a third person shooter where you will find various guns to use to defend yourself from the darkness. The enemies are mostly humans that have been “possessed” by the darkness and seem to have swirling shadows around them. These enemies are invincible until you destroy the shadows around them with your primary weapon, a flashlight. After the shadows are gone you can blast them with your regular guns. This is one of the only games I’ve played where the flare gun is the best weapon in the game. The flare gun totally destroys every enemy on screen with its bright flash.

Pros:
+Excellent story – practically an interactive movie.
+Some scary parts when the enemies come after you in the dark.
+Easy Steam achievements in this game :)
+Cheap – the game was in a Humble Bundle for $1

Cons:
-Lower replay value due to it being so cinematic. Wait about a year before playing it again.
-This is one of those games that can give you a headache when you play, not sure why. Probably because of the swirling shadows that are everywhere.
-The game heated up my video card despite being on low settings.

Overall I would recommend the game to anyone who enjoys horror, psychological thrillers, or just good stories. There is some very mild puzzle solving in the game but it’s mostly straightforward. If you get lost, just run towards the light! The sequel Alan Wake’s American Nightmare is a bit of a letdown afterwards. The same game mechanics apply but there is much less variety and less of a horror aspect. You can probably find the two games for cheap though since they seem to be on sale quite often for less than $5. The Steam edition includes 2 DLCs: The Signal, and The Writer. I skipped over them the first time I played the game but I’m trying them now.

reviewText:
Excellent game that is well worth your time. The setting is great (very Twin Peaks) and the whole feel of the game is that of quality. The story and the characters are interesting and the gameplay mechanics are fun and satisfying.
It can be quite challenging at times, but nothing crazy or punishing (like Dark Souls for example). If you enjoy story based, 3rd person action/horror/adventure games, you will likely love this game. It is one of the best 3rd person games that I have played and I really hope that they make a sequel at some point, as it would be a shame for them not to.

The American Nightmare spin-off game isn't bad either, but it isn't as good as the main game. It's more action based and a lot smaller. It's still quite clever and enjoyable though.

This one is definitely recommended though. Loved it.

Just to add. The game is very well optimised and will run on fairly modest machines (by today's standards) at 1080p and the highest settings.

reviewText:
the Good:  - atmosphere, atmosphere, atmosphere
- the story, the characters, the flashlight, the darkness
- graphics are great, soundtrack is awesome

the Bad:  - movement and driving controls are a little loose/imprecise

the Awesome:  - the Anderson brothers and their farm

This is a fun game and the combat is made strategic with the use of the flashlight (and other light sources).  The opening prologue stage didn't impress me much.  I'd recommend waiting until you play the first real stage (make it to the gas station) before you make a decision on this one.  For full effect, play in the dark with a good sound arrangement.  The setting is beautiful and frightening at the same time.  The more I played, the more it drew me in.

reviewText: Alan Wake is a must play for fans of third person survival horror games, it satisfies both craves. This is one of the most gorgeous looking games i've ever played and the landscapes unfold like images from a night mare, anyone susceptible to jump scares will have there hands full with this gem, the games at it's best when your alone in the wood's after dark with a enemy sneaking up behind you. The game play unlike most horror games is superb and sits on a throne above the rest in it's genre, each chapter introduces a new game play mechanic, the pacing makes it so you never get bored. The enemies and there AI are a joy and combat is very fun and is complimented by great control, my only complaint is theres no way to quickly turn 190 degrees without moving the mouse, it can sometimes be the death of you. The story is another selling point, it's like playing a really good steven king book, it's suspenseful and has a very satisfying ending, great characters, one in particular is Alan's best friend and offers great comedic relief that isn't too much to hurt the games serious vibe. All of the characters are fantastic and the dialogue is always engaging, expect twist and turns by the end of each chapter. The game took me about 11 hours to finish minus the included special chapters that are included as free dlc, the free dlc is roughly 2 and a half hours long and is my biggest disappointment with the game, it's unnecessary and doesn't add much. i cant praise this one enough, just give it a try.

reviewText:
I've had this on my wishlist for sometime now, when it went on sale for the 2013 christmas holiday @ $3.50 for the Collector's Edition, I couldn't pass it up.
I really enjoyed playing this game, I am a hardcore fps gamer, but not a huge fan of 3rd person, although I didn't mind at all when playing Alan Wake.
Alan Wake has a good feel to it, a bit creepy when running around the forest and enemies appear! I love the concept of the light. Standing in light protects you from enemies and you must point and boost your flashlight onto enemies before shooting them. You can use flares, flaregun and flashbangs along with a pistol, two different shotguns and hunting rifle.
There are a lot of hidden items through-out the forest you must collect.

Also comes with steam trading cards and plenty of achievements! Check out more on the game if your interested!

reviewText: What better way to experience a thriller, than play the main character? Alan Wake is the story of a man living on the edge, an adventurous writer who ultimately suffers the same fate as the characters in his stories. The immersion and detail given to the story more than makes up for the repetitive scenery and backtracking, and will leave you on the edge of your seat each time you enter combat; this is a must buy purely for the story.

reviewText:
Alan Wake is a story-driven phychological thriller with one of the best plot in the genre. You play as Alan Wake, a burnt out writer who visits the small town of Bright Falls with his wife, Alice, for inspiration for his upcoming book called 'The Departure'. After the first night in Bright Falls, Alice is gone missing under mysterious circumstances, and Alan suddenly finds himself in the story of his unfinished horror novel. In order to save his wife, Alan needs to finish the story and find out of the dark secret of Bright Falls.

The game is divided into 6 base episodes and 2 extra episodes, each starting with a short recap of the events of the previous one (except for the first episode of course.)
During the span of the episodes, the story slowly unfolds, and the pieces of puzzle come together to form an outstanding plot.
So, is Alan Wake worth playing? Yes, it is. Definitely but only for the story.

Gameplay wise sadly it's one of the laziest work I've ever seen, there's zero effort in building tension past episode 2. All you get is cheap jump scares and massive hordes of enemies.
And after a while you realize that the game only brings frustration and makes you angry, yet the plot is so good you will keep going just to get to the end of the story.

PROS:
- Graphics look pretty neat, especially the lighting and the landscapes.
- The story! I can't emphasize this enough, the biggest value of the game is the story!
- The lore and characters. The developers put a lot of details into the world of Alan Wake!
- Radio shows, manuscripts further extends the knowledge of the plot.
- Night Springs. An in-game TV show that's inspired by Twilight Zone.


CONS:
- Gameplay is a trainwreck!
- Massive hordes of enemies ruin the tension and atmosphere. It also causes frustration and anger.
- Alan Wake's stamina is lower than a 80 year grandpa who's been shot with a tranquilizer. Translation: he can't more than 10-15meters without being completely exhausted. I know the game is supposed to be a survival game, but come on!
- The gameplay gets extremely repetitive and predictable at a certain point: see a barrel, or a broken down car? 99% they are poltergeist objects and will jump on you. See a generator that you need to restart? You will get swarmed by enemies as soon as you go near it.
- Despite having collectibles and hidden items, the game does NOT like you wandering off the linear passage and often punishes you with waves of enemies.


TLDR: Play Alan Wake for the story!

reviewText:
The light fantastic (almost)

Credit is due Remedy for making ALAN WAKE a story-driven game. It’s a partial success, though not a complete one. They have entirely eschewed the typical RPG tropes of dialogue trees and progression choices in favour of a linear, non-interactive structure. The story is played out in a series of cut-scenes and simple A to B tasks. Basically you just have to battle your way from one place to the next. There’s certainly a place for this type of game, and when it’s done well (á la Half-Life 2) it can be very rewarding. Unlike Half-Life 2, however, ALAN WAKE doesn’t quite pull it off. Firstly, there isn’t enough humour. There’s some but it would have benefited from more. And the story isn’t exactly original. But the main problem for me was the combat. I hated the way control is wrenched away from the player every time enemies approach. I get why they did it (there’s no other way of knowing they’re coming, apart from some audible warnings) but I often found myself disoriented when the camera had finished sweeping around and control had retuned. Several times the sweep lasted so long that by the time I had control again the enemies were right on me and it was impossible to avoid taking a hit. Frustrating to say the least. On the plus side the environments look very good and it’s quite atmospheric (although not as creepy as I would have liked – Silent Hill still sets the bar for that). One other thing worth noting is that I found the special episode, The Writer, to be better than what had gone before. It’s even more atmospheric and far more inventive. Overall this is a good game if not an outstanding one.

3/5

reviewText:
Alan Wake is less a horror game and more of a story experience. The horror aspects are all but lost unless you are playing on the hardest difficulty, which takes two or three playthroughs to unlock, and the difference is palpable.

On anything but nightmare mode, a shadowy man will pop out on occasion and after going shine shine shine, glack glack glack, the threat is gone and you can continue with the story. On nightmare mode the game is completely different. Hordes of shadowy abominations of our reality will pour from the woods while you desperately sprint towards the next pinprick of light only to have it wink out as you near it. Then you pop a flare and continue the full tilt sprint to the next shining becon of hope, only for Wake to get tired and then get an axe in the back of his head.

Nightmare mode seems to be the way the game was MEANT to be played, but you can't access it without 2 other plythroughs, which is simply asking too much. Personally I play through a game once and am done with it unless theres some crazy alternate endings that I HAVE to get, wich there aren't here. Which brings me to the story.

Alan Wake's story is a cross between Stephen King and Twin Peaks, with a heavy dose of lovecraft mixed in. I will not spoil anything in this, but the story is truly the best aspect of this game. It keeps the player thinking about what will happen next and where this ♥♥♥♥ storm of nightmares will end up.

In the end, Alan Wake is not a particularly scary game, unless played on the highest difficulty. The story and immersion are it's strong points, but one playthrough is probably enough, unless you are a completionist, then this game has plenty for you in the forms of thermoses scattered around the playing areas. This game is a definite 8/10, nothing ♥♥♥♥-your-pants amazing, but still enough that everyone should play it one time through.

reviewText:
Genre: 3rd person shooter, thriller, action, drama
My Opinion: B+
Length: ~10hours
Replay: Low

Its a 3rd person suspense thiller shooter. The game's visuals are great and there are some really scenic areas in the game, along with well done models and textures for the time. The only things that were not top notch were the combat, and the driving. The combat was slightly clunky, along with the ability to basically dodge out of the way of pretty much any attack, and the driving was just insufferable, since the cars would break down far too often since they get damaged when you run into enemies.

Overall, its a fun game, worth taking a look at if you are ok with 3rd person shooters, not anything super exceptional, since the story is pretty bog standard for a suspense thriller, where it feels like a typical Stephen King novel.
