reviewText: This game is a must-buy for a multitude of reasons. For one, the protagonist, Alan Wake, is a very likeable character; he is written exceptionally well and he, along with his best friend Barry Wheeler, is often believable based on the decisions he makes and his reaction to the world crumbling around him. The story in this game is also very rich and makes you stop in your tracks to think about it quite often... It's just something that we haven't seen a lot of. There are also many allusions to existing novels such as The Lord of the Rings and The Shining, so readers are in for a treat. Finally, the gameplay is completely original and the concept has been executed to near perfection (It's a tad bit repetitive at times, but still tense and exciting).\n\nHopefully, you will make the right decision (BUY THE GAME!) and savour every moment of it. It's a great addition to your library of games and definitely needs to be played from start to finish. Oh, and PC players get the two DLC packs free of charge.

reviewText:
One of my favourite games I have played. It is not a pop-up scare game but works more on a persons psyche, which beautifully mirrors Stephen King and his works.

As for the shooting aspect and over game mechanics: I really can't say much, it isn't meant to be a shooter so I didn't expect the aim mechanics to be 100% accurate (also to be fair he is a writer not a military soldier).

Just for anyone borderline about buying this game, a bit like Amnesia: dark descent, DO NOT buy it to win. This game has a great story, which is its main focus and running through the game at record speed won't let you enjoy the environment or be enthralled by its storyline.
Though I must digress that some characters could have been drawn out a bit better like Wake's wife. It's hard to sympathise for someone you only meet in the opening cutscene of the game, so no emotional attachment leads to a longer timeframe to actually begin your association with the protagonist

reviewText:
This is a terrific game. The real kickers of it are the story and the atmosphere. The story involves a writer named Alan Wake who goes on a search for his missing wife, Alice. But is he really searching for her or is there something bigger, more devastating going on here? The atmosphere envelopes the player in moody darkness as Alan traverses the great outdoors and fights his way past the possessed dark known as the Taken.

The gameplay can get quite repetitive, but different segments diversify it up (such as surviving an assault with loads of ammo and batteries for your precious flashlight). Light is the key in this game, as the player must make his way to each lampost emitting light which is always another checkpoint. Some may find this repetitive as well, but I was always relieved to get to the next one as many of my resources (my batteries and ammo) were quite exhausted. I played the game on normal and while there were some moments that inflicted great frustrations, all in all it was a great experience.

It is a survival horror game, and while it is not as scary as Silent Hill or Amnesia, it definitely gives you moments of panic and/or fright. For me, these moments typically came because Alan can not run fast for too long as he gets tired and slows down. This can prove to be frustrating if you are being chased by too many Taken (as I was on many an occasion), but I believe it was purposely done this way, else the game would be too easy if Alan could just run faster than the Taken to each checkpoint and never have to stop, turn around, flash and kill as many Taken as possible, and go back to running.

Overall, I had an enjoyable experience with this game. I would recommend that everyone who plays it, also play the 2 Special DLC chapters upon completion of the base story. This will provide closure upon finishing the two specials, or at least more closure than the ending of Alan Wake by itself.

8/10

reviewText:
One of the best atmospheric thriller games I've played in recent memories. If you're looking for gore and demons and half-naked nurses, move along. If you're looking for something like a Stephen King-esque horror/thriller with supernatural elements and tense combat, pull up a chair. Let me tell you about Alan Wake.

Alan Wake was originally to be a launch Xbox 360 title. But it got delayed. Then it got delayed more, and more, and people started to wonder if it would ever come. Then it came, and it was polarizing. People seemed to either love it or hate it, depending on expectations. But one thing was clear, it was creepy, it had some unique twists and game mechanics, and it looks beautiful now that it's been brought to PC.

Alan Wake is a struggling writer; he just killed off his main character and is looking to start a new series. Alice, his wife, suggests a vacation to get his mind off the pressures of work, and they go to a small town, where they've rented a cabin. The townsfolk seem a bit... strange... and as night falls over the cabin and the lake surrounding it, things take a turn for the worse. Alice's scream pierces the night, and Alan grips his flashlight tightly.

Achievement-hunters may gripe at Alan Wake's collectibles. Some are fun and relatively easy to find with some work; manuscript pages from the novel Alan never remembers writing, televisions that show short Twilight Zone"-esque episodes of a series Alan wrote for and radio broadcasts that indicate events going on elsewhere in the town. But then there are the can pyramids to shoot over

recommended: nor did they have a purpose outside of achievements.\n\nLip-synching is also a bit of an issue at times. When you're dealing with rendered models

I played it on a Asus G75 notebook with a 660M (2GB) and didn't have performance issues, just some sttuter from time to time. Overall I'll give it a 9/10.

reviewText:
If you enjoy the Silent Hill games, you will definitely enjoy Alan Wake. I am merely making the Silent Hill reference to show you what a great story-driven and carefully crafted game Alan Wake is. It is certainly not a Silent Hill clone and is very unique.

Clever story, fun combat, and some very tense moments. The atmosphere and story work together perfectly. I couldn't wait to see what was going to happen next, and some parts of the game will really get your heart pumping. I won't spoil anything. I'll just say some of the scenes get really intense. There are a few puzzles thrown into the mix, but they are pretty basic and easy. The story and fun combat is where this game shines.

I will admit that some parts of the game were really hard for me, even on easy mode, but you can get through them with a little learning (learn to find the hidden item caches, look for alternate paths, run instead of fight, etc). I don't fault the game for this because it made me think of alternate solutions and made it feel really satisfying when I finally beat a part of the game that was giving me problems. Don't worry about it too much though. Checkpoints are encountered often so you won't have to replay much if you die.

Picked it up for $5 during a sale, but would have no problem paying the full price. You can easily tell within moments of playing that the creators were passionate about making a great game. It's an awesome game worth playing for people who enjoy adventure/action horror games.

reviewText: Alan Wake is a 3rd person shooter/action-adventure game originally released for the Xbox 360 and ported over to the PC. The PC port is done well, with all the graphical options you could want, and the DLC from the console game included with the purchase.\n\nThe story for Alan Wake is the real standout. Your character, Alan Wake, is a famous writing who is struggling with writer's block. You go on a vacation to the Pacific Northwest with your wife, where things begin to get supernatural. The game is split into 1-2 hour segments called episodes, like a TV show. At the end of each episode, there is a closing song and title screen. Each following episode begins with a previously on..." segment. This breaks the game up into nice 1-2 chunks of playtime
date: and also allows for a natural jump to exploring some back story at the beginning of each segment. I really enjoyed how this aspect played out
recommended: and would love to see it in other games. The story kept me engrossed all the way through
hoursPlayed: and did not overstay its welcome. I was anxiously anticipating the end
voteText: not to finally be done with the game
helpfulPercent: but to find out what actually happens. I couldn't ask for anything more from a game in that regard.\n\nThe gameplay does leave a bit to be desired. There is a very limited selection of weapons
votesHelpful: and you will be fighting the same enemies over and over again. The Taken
votesTotal: as the baddies are labeled in this game
votesFunny: are not especially varied. There are the normal kind
commentsCount: the strong kind
column16: and the fast kind. You will see combinations of these throughout your time with Alan Wake. Be prepared to fight plenty of lumberjacks as you run through the forests of the Pacific Northwest. There are several types of collectables to look for along the way. Most have no effect on the story
column17: however the manuscripts tie in to the game and show you what to expect next. It's a shame that the game requires two playthroughs to collect them all.\n\nThe graphics are fairly good when you consider that the game was originally released in 2010 on console. The animation of the main character could have used some work to appear more lifelike. The environment looks great
column18: but you will be seeing a lot of forest. I was growing a little tired of that setting by the end. The FMVs are jarring when they come on
column19: since the graphics take a notable step down from the main gameplay. That may be a result of the graphics getting a small bump when moved to PC.\n\nThe controls are adequate for what you will be doing the most of
column20: running and shooting. I used a 360 controller and had no issues. The only difficulties were in some of the platforming sequences. I found myself missing some jumps or running off the edge of small platforms. I would not have missed those sections if they were not included.\n\nThe music is fantastic
column21: and plays a minor role in the story. At the end of each episode
column22: a song plays over the title screen. It has some connection to what you have just seen. A mix of licensed and original songs are used
column23: with the original songs really fitting in nicely in tone and quality.\n\nOverall I would wholeheartedly recommend Alan Wake for a playthrough. The story is engrossing
column24: and the gameplay
column25: while repetitive at times
column26: moves quickly along to keep you interested. I do not see a lot of replayability in this title
column27: since the story is the main selling point. However
column28: there is enough length to keep you satisfied with your purchase on one playthrough. I recommend playing the special episodes after finishing the main game
column29: since they add a bit more closure to the experience. Those can be found under the episodes option on the main menu.\n\nGrade: B+"

reviewText: Alan Wake takes a lot from John Carpenter's In the Mouth of Madness, which I love. Alan, a horror novel writer, awakens after a car crash while on vacation with his wife unable to remember an entire weeks worth of events. His wife is now missing and his works of fiction have been made a reality in his absence. He must now navigate a small logging town called Bright Falls and survive countless encounters with the Taken (shadowy, derranged campers/woodsmen turned violent) in order to find and rescue his beloved wife.\n\nThis game is episodic so its broken apart nicely and feels like it could very well have been its own hbo or amc miniseries. All in all its been a lot of fun so far. I reccommend buying it if you see it on sale, its worth it.

reviewText:
Alan Wake began its tumultuous history as a state-of-the-art showcase for PC graphics in 2009... that is until the publishing rights were purchased by Microsoft Game Studios, postponing the title until 2010 for exclusivity on the Xbox 360.

Two years on, one of the best survival horror titles this side of Amnesia at last comes home to the PC. Featuring gorgeously updated graphics and additional content, Alan Wake's technical merits complement a truly superb and chilling narrative.

Leave the lights on.

reviewText:
Alan Wake is ambitious if nothing else. It took the makers years to make (which included many delays), and there is clear evidence throughout the game that it was originally meant to be at least semi-open world rather than sectioned into levels. Once it did come out though, it heralded a new style of narrative with chapters played like episodes of a TV show, replete with visual summaries of the previous episode at the start of each of them. That desire to experiment with narrative in the game is easily the best part, and even though it's very heavily inspired by Stephen King, it's still a very original style for gaming and will keep you playing through even the dullest gameplay portions.

And that's the main problem with Alan Wake, the gameplay. Now, that's not to say it's even that bad, it's actually pretty enjoyable and adds a lot of tension that really helps the game's atmosphere. The game even introduces new and interesting enemies for a while that keep you on your toes! But somewhere around the halfway point the game gets bored with introducing new gameplay elements, and of course shortly after that point you will too. The game really does start to drag towards the end, and if you're anything like me it will feel like a real grind to finish it and see what happens to the story. Aaaand then there's no satisfactory conclusion either. The game wants you to play the episodes that were released as DLC, but due to lukewarm reception (the game already got boring, and the DLC adds nothing while rewarding you with even less substantial story), they got cut short at just the 2. I should mention Alan Wake 2 is rumoured to be in the works, so there is that anyway.

But to cut this short, Alan Wake is absolutely fantastic for half of the game, and then falls short towards the end. Despite this, it's frankly a must play for what it does right, so I recommend it for sure.

reviewText:
Top game! So much immersion in this one. Looking at the graphics (max settings), this game looks incredibly good for the time it was made. This game isn't much about graphics though, it's about telling you a story.
On overall I really liked this game, it was very deep. But playing it for 10 hours straight, I did notice that the combat was pretty flat: it was always the same.. pop off their darkness and shoot them a couple of times and they die. Then you have flares and flashbangs that add a little extra, but that was it. Fortunately enough in the DLC: American Nightmare there's much more weapons. That DLC was also much enjoyable, even though I finished nightmare mode in just 3 hours! It really completes the whole story.. [spoiler alert] Because at the end Alan Wake is still trapped in his darkness, but when you finish American Nightmare you get out of that.

Story: 9/10
Gameplay: 8/10
Graphics: 8/10
Dialogue: 8/10
Extra adds: 7/10 (especially 'Put the lime in the coconut' made me laugh very hard!)

reviewText:
NOTE: This is my opinions and thoughts of the game and not an overall view if the game for general audience. As with many reviews and opinions, take this with a grain of salt and do your own research. It is a shame I have to put up these notes telling people what they should already know on to do their own, but due to inflammatory commentry, I do.


A game much different than anything I ever played. The best way to describe the game is a survival horror done int he way of an interactive short tv series with an overlying narrative like that of a visualized book. The gameplay is magnificent and controls are at times a bit extensive but easy to get used to. It's very environmentally interactive and nearly as realistic and logical as a game can get. This game is fun in terms of reading a good mystery novel, only you're in control and replace the need to read text, there are stunning visuals, haunting melodies, and the goal to help you, Alan wake, discover what is reality and what is fiction, if reality still even exists. Writers truly get lost in their work...

reviewText:
Absolutely loved this game, if there's one series that's brought me back to the silent hill era it's Alan wake (Yes series because of the expansions)..  Intense thriller story line that grips you from start to finish.  Stunning visuals and an interesting gameplay mechanic thrown in (The flashlight).  You'll never want to stop playing.

So far I've beat it twice and it still never gets old.  There aren't many games that compell me to beat them once let alone another time.

The downside to all this is that it's pretty linear.  I'm not speaking from my point of view on this one because I don't mind but some might find the on rails action a bit stale.

9/10 on graphics
10/10 gameplay
6/10 on replayability (Only because it's a total mind bender and I don't find games like these offer much in another playthrough...  Even though I beat it twice many may not want to brave the game for a second playthrough)

reviewText:
You start off as Alan who makes his way to Bright Falls with his wife Alice after he is in need of a vacation. Upon arrival to the cavern where you are staying, the lights go out and you need to turn the power back on. You hear Alice scream and you later rush back to the cabin to find she has disappeared. From then on you are trying to put together what has happened to Alice whilst progressing through the levels taking on chainsaw wielding, axe throwing, crazy ♥♥♥ maniacs. Only these maniacs aren't human. Bullets only hurt them if you remove the shadowy appiration from them using a flashlight, flash grenades or flares. Only then will your bullets do any damage.

The Good;-

Nice Graphics
Amazing Story
Replayability
Great Atmosphere

The Bad;-

Camera Angles
Repetitive Combat

Just finished the game for a second time (first on the 360 way back when it came out) and it's still a great game. If you can pick this up on sale id highly reccomend it!

Overall Rating 8/10

reviewText:
One of my favourite games I have played. It is not a pop-up scare game but works more on a persons psyche, which beautifully mirrors Stephen King and his works.

As for the shooting aspect and over game mechanics: I really can't say much, it isn't meant to be a shooter so I didn't expect the aim mechanics to be 100% accurate (also to be fair he is a writer not a military soldier).

Just for anyone borderline about buying this game, a bit like Amnesia: dark descent, DO NOT buy it to win. This game has a great story, which is its main focus and running through the game at record speed won't let you enjoy the environment or be enthralled by its storyline.
Though I must digress that some characters could have been drawn out a bit better like Wake's wife. It's hard to sympathise for someone you only meet in the opening cutscene of the game, so no emotional attachment leads to a longer timeframe to actually begin your association with the protagonist
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Console port or not, Alan Wake is by far one of the best games, period, I've played in quite some time.  The story centers around Alan Wake (didn't see that coming, did you? :P) a writer who gets caught up in supernatural events.  The story isn't the most original in the world, but it gives credit where credit is due.  Homages to Stephen King and Twin Peaks, among others, give Alan Wake a surrealistic charm.

The 'Light vs the Dark' mechanic works extremely well.  Flashlight batteries and ammo are most definitely resources to be used judiciously (run out and you'll be sweating bullets).

Personally, I loved this game mechanic.  Nowhere in Alan Wake do you ever find random ammo and battery dumps just so you can stock up.  When you do find them, you'll probably faint in relief.  IMO, the game ALWAYS gives you just enough resources to survive the various encounters.  No more, no less.  How you survice, IF you survive, will require a little thinking on your part.

Additionally, every 'encounter' and discovery serves to drive the story forward; 'filler material' is almost non-existant.  Very few games out there can make that claim.  Be patient as the game is like any well written thriller (film or literature).  There are 'red herrings' and detours but they too serve the overall story.

The ending will certainly leave some peope confused but never fear!  Simply go the Main Menu, options, episodes, and voila!  The two DLC that come with the game, 'The Signal' and 'The Writer' will be there for you to continue the story.  <'The Signal' is the episode you'll want to start with>

I bought Alan Wake during a Steam sale at 75% off though I would have gladly paid full price for it.  It is that good.

reviewText: Alan Wake is a 3rd person shooter/action-adventure game originally released for the Xbox 360 and ported over to the PC. The PC port is done well, with all the graphical options you could want, and the DLC from the console game included with the purchase.\n\nThe story for Alan Wake is the real standout. Your character, Alan Wake, is a famous writing who is struggling with writer's block. You go on a vacation to the Pacific Northwest with your wife, where things begin to get supernatural. The game is split into 1-2 hour segments called episodes, like a TV show. At the end of each episode, there is a closing song and title screen. Each following episode begins with a previously on..." segment. This breaks the game up into nice 1-2 chunks of playtime
date: and also allows for a natural jump to exploring some back story at the beginning of each segment. I really enjoyed how this aspect played out
recommended: and would love to see it in other games. The story kept me engrossed all the way through
hoursPlayed: and did not overstay its welcome. I was anxiously anticipating the end
voteText: not to finally be done with the game
helpfulPercent: but to find out what actually happens. I couldn't ask for anything more from a game in that regard.\n\nThe gameplay does leave a bit to be desired. There is a very limited selection of weapons

Be prepared to fight plenty of lumberjacks as you run through the forests of the Pacific Northwest. There are several types of collectables to look for along the way. Most have no effect on the story

It's a shame that the game requires two playthroughs to collect them all.\n\nThe graphics are fairly good when you consider that the game was originally released in 2010 on console. The animation of the main character could have used some work to appear more lifelike. The environment looks great

I found myself missing some jumps or running off the edge of small platforms. I would not have missed those sections if they were not included.\n\nThe music is fantastic

reviewText:
There's some stuff this game got so right, and other things it got very wrong

I LOVE the Stephen King style Great story and resolution

However, the variety in enemies is very lacking... There's axe-wielding sarcastic lumberjacks, axe-wielding sarcastic park rangers, axe-wielding sarcastic police officers, and axe-wielding sarcastic farmers. You also get attacked by an assorment of inanimate objects (puddles, barrels, car tires), but overall there wasn't much variety. I would have preferred a crosshair and no auto-aiming if the control scheme allowed it.

The controls were a little wonky. The over-the-shoulder angle makes walking on narrow pathways a PITA. Also, for some weird reason, I had to re-bind my jump key (numpad / - I know, weird) every time I played

The graphics and sound (especially the sound) were done beautifully and fit the mood very well..

The pacing and difficulty weren't really there at all. The story follows an episodic pattern, which works well, but the game itself didn't pace well. Climaxes would often happen near the beginning of the chapter, followed by boring stretches of nothing for long times. The fights didn't really get more difficult. The most difficult one happened in the middle of chapter 2 or 3 (on the viewing platofmr). Everything else before and after that was too easy. The final fight way so easy I thought i was doing it wrong.

Also, the product placement was a little over-the-top... You had to regularly pick up Energizer (tm) batteries, and if you got lucky you could find Energizer Lithium (tm) batteries. You see a couple of xboxes in random places, and regular Verizon billboards.

So yeah, I will say the monotony of running through the woods killing lumberjacks" was my biggest peeve about it I will give Sarcastic Lumberjack Hunter a rating of 3/5."

reviewText:
Genre: 3rd person shooter, thriller, action, drama
My Opinion: B+
Length: ~10hours
Replay: Low

Its a 3rd person suspense thiller shooter. The game's visuals are great and there are some really scenic areas in the game, along with well done models and textures for the time. The only things that were not top notch were the combat, and the driving. The combat was slightly clunky, along with the ability to basically dodge out of the way of pretty much any attack, and the driving was just insufferable, since the cars would break down far too often since they get damaged when you run into enemies.

Overall, its a fun game, worth taking a look at if you are ok with 3rd person shooters, not anything super exceptional, since the story is pretty bog standard for a suspense thriller, where it feels like a typical Stephen King novel.

reviewText: (7.5) Alan Wake is suspense-filled and thriller. The storyline and plot is very developed, with a strong connection between the characters. The game itself evokes strong character traits, that are almost unforgetable. It is split into episodes, as if it was a TV show. Being somewhat challenging and fast paced, it can often times be confusing and hard to choke down the story, pretty much being the consequence for being too fast-paced. Also it can becomes repetitive and boring, being that there is no diversity in the types of objectives, which could also lead into some serious confusion if you don't focus on it. The ending itself isn't very strong, either. Perhaps a cliff-hanger for a sequel?

reviewText:
Alan's Wank is the latest game by the developer that brought you the classic racing game ReVolt (Dreamcast version only) and the hugely influential Maximum Carnage that introduced the revolutionary mechanic 'Gullet Time'.

You control Alan Awake -- an award-winning dolphin novelist -- And aim his fleshlight at crows and stuff. WEEEIRD...! The music also adds a lot to the game. Play it loud in stereo, dude! You can buy the music on CD from Nintendo if your Nintendo isn't hooked up to a stereo system. Barry Wheeler remebers music in the old days, but Alan is TRULY with the times (so to speak). His music is great for listening, just beat an episode and listen to the music without the game sound effects. Speaking of sound effects; you'll notice the quality of the echos in the caves and Alan's ape-noises.

Bottom line: Get it now. The graphics are an example of a revolution. Play control is very responsive and monkey-feeling. Alan Stank is TRULY perfect. If you do not get this amazing new generation of dolphin-novelist madness, then you are STUPID. Yes, I know, that's insulting, but it's also the truth. If you are a true video game fan, you will not hesitate in the slightest bit to buy this incredible piece of video game history.

reviewText:
From Remedy, the creators of Max Payne 1 and 2 comes Alan Wake, another story heavy Third Person Shooter.

But while Max Payne shines in action, Alan Wake shines in atmosphere. It will last you around 18 hours. It has a Metracritic score of 83 (critics) and 8.0 (users).

reviewText: This game grabbed me in a way I had forgotten that gaming could grab me. It pulled me into a deep and engaging story. It scared the heck out of me. It made me care about the characters and what would become of them. Much has been said about its developmental change from open world to an episodic structure, but after playing this game through twice now, I wouldn't have it any other way. Also, despite the linearity, the game greatly benefits from this open world engine; on a current gaming system, players can see to lush forests and rustic towns to the horizon. This 'Twin Peaks/American Gothic' presentation is what's so gripping. The game feels like a TV drama, down to the 'previously on Alan Wake' montages and the 'closing credits' music between episodes. So much about this game is obviously the product of love and pure creative passion. Remedy: I wish you'd made Max Payne 3.\n\nTechnically, the engine is tight, finely tuned and runs beautifully on all detail settings. The lighting and related effects are superb. The motion and control are also responsive and smooth. There was only one bug in which all objects but the lights would be rendered, resulting in an almost entirely black screen. This only occurred twice and restarting the game and the chapter fixed the situation. It must be noted that I have completed the game and its DLC three times; the first time was an all night session into mid morning. The game is worth it.

reviewText:
This Game is a carefully crafted masterpiece.
The characters are very well written, the gameplay is unique and challenging. On top of that the player is thrown in a dense and disturbing atmosphere similar to cinematic classics such as The Shining".
There are quite some ironic cultural references as well.
Remedy did a great job by implementing a whole load of details featuring TV-Sequences
hoursPlayed:
and pages of a manuscript you are trapped in.
The succesful fusion of Action and Story makes Alan Wake a more than just enjoyable game.
People looking for a linear single-player shooter or a horror game like Amnesia won't like this game too much.
Story and Gameplay are the keywords to describe the "Alan Wake"-experience."

reviewText:
A brilliantly written game with a very spooky cinematic feel to it.

Feels like the kind of game Stephen King would write if he was a game designer. (This was obviously the intention of the game's creators, as they refer to King from the get-go. :p)

There's a nice deep mythology to the game involving Alan Wake as a writer and husband, the town of Bright Falls as a place in both past and present, as well as supernatural elements that have a way of bleeding through the gaps between fact and fiction.

The game mechanics are fun, and the whole mysterious feel to the story keeps you coming back for more till it's all done.

5/5

reviewText: Waited years for the PC port while fighting off the urge to buy a console simply to play this one story-driven game. I both love and hate Stephen King, and love Twin Peaks wholeheartedly; luckily, AW goes above and beyond most all of King's output to deliver something entirely on another level, reaching more in the line of Ellis' underappreciated Glamora--god, this is getting obnoxious. Anyway, I loved it more than I expected. The pomo narrative selfconsciousness and general tomfoolery got me kickin'. The repetitive combat didn't so much, but I found myself always eager to look past that and see and hear Wake's next steps.

reviewText:
After having played Alan Wake on xbox360 and now on PC I can definitely recommend this game. It does a really good job at emmersing the player into the dark and beautifully designed world, this is one of the most detailed and well crafted game worlds I've seen. The atmosphere, story and pacing is really well done and is probably where the game shines the most. Don't expect a horror game, this is an adventure/thriller that takes the player on an nail-biting adventure that won't be forgotten easily.

The gameplay and mechanics are fun and fluid with some room for improvement for buggy running and jumping controls. Other than that, the gameplay is quite unique and fun making for some intense, interesting and horrifying moments. I've played this with both keyboard/mouse and controller. The game plays easier with keyboard/mouse since it makes aiming and camera controls easier to do. A controller is definitely not required but it does come down to preference.

Definitely a game that must be played if you like Thriller/Adventure story based games with unique 3rd person gameplay.

reviewText:
One of my favourite games I have played. It is not a pop-up scare game but works more on a persons psyche, which beautifully mirrors Stephen King and his works.

As for the shooting aspect and over game mechanics: I really can't say much, it isn't meant to be a shooter so I didn't expect the aim mechanics to be 100% accurate (also to be fair he is a writer not a military soldier).

Just for anyone borderline about buying this game, a bit like Amnesia: dark descent, DO NOT buy it to win. This game has a great story, which is its main focus and running through the game at record speed won't let you enjoy the environment or be enthralled by its storyline.
Though I must digress that some characters could have been drawn out a bit better like Wake's wife. It's hard to sympathise for someone you only meet in the opening cutscene of the game, so no emotional attachment leads to a longer timeframe to actually begin your association with the protagonist

reviewText:
Console port or not, Alan Wake is by far one of the best games, period, I've played in quite some time.  The story centers around Alan Wake (didn't see that coming, did you? :P) a writer who gets caught up in supernatural events.  The story isn't the most original in the world, but it gives credit where credit is due.  Homages to Stephen King and Twin Peaks, among others, give Alan Wake a surrealistic charm.

The 'Light vs the Dark' mechanic works extremely well.  Flashlight batteries and ammo are most definitely resources to be used judiciously (run out and you'll be sweating bullets).

Personally, I loved this game mechanic.  Nowhere in Alan Wake do you ever find random ammo and battery dumps just so you can stock up.  When you do find them, you'll probably faint in relief.  IMO, the game ALWAYS gives you just enough resources to survive the various encounters.  No more, no less.  How you survice, IF you survive, will require a little thinking on your part.

Additionally, every 'encounter' and discovery serves to drive the story forward; 'filler material' is almost non-existant.  Very few games out there can make that claim.  Be patient as the game is like any well written thriller (film or literature).  There are 'red herrings' and detours but they too serve the overall story.

The ending will certainly leave some peope confused but never fear!  Simply go the Main Menu, options, episodes, and voila!  The two DLC that come with the game, 'The Signal' and 'The Writer' will be there for you to continue the story.  <'The Signal' is the episode you'll want to start with>

I bought Alan Wake during a Steam sale at 75% off though I would have gladly paid full price for it.  It is that good.

reviewText:
If you play games for the game play mechanics, then you might like this title. Alan Wake is a third-person survival horror mystery. The main character is a writer, so he is portrayed as not very athletic. This translates into the feeling of slugish and unresponsive movement. Enemies must first be cleansed of darkness by shining a flashlight on them for varying amounts of time (3-10 seconds). I found this mechanic to be a bit frustrating later in the game. The flashlight also acts as the targeting reticule. There are 5 different guns available: revolver, double-barrel shotgun, pump-action shotgun, hunting rifle and the flare gun. The flare gun acts as a rocket launcher since all of the enemies are weak to light. There are also flashbangs and road flares. Ammo is somewhat scare, and there will be times when the player will be out of ammo if care isn't taken. There is no upgrade system in this game.

If you play games for the storytelling, then you will probably like this title.  The main character and his wife go on vacation to a small pacific northwest town in an attempt to cure his writer's block. I found the characters to be mostly interesting. I also though that the dialog and voice acting were very good.

The design of the world and the characters is very good in my opinion. The lighting is mostly dark, though. There are a few sections of the story that take place during the day, but most of it is during the night.

I was annoyed by the frailty and sluggishness of the main character, and the fact that most of the game takes place at very low light levels. This obviously gave a sense of urgancy to everything, but this changed to annoyance for me towards the later parts of the story. I also foung the game to be more challenging than I would have expected on the lowest difficulty setting.

Overall, I enjoyed my time with this title. Aside from the annoyances, I found the story to be well worth it.

reviewText: Страх - это чувство, которое может заставить нас совершать немыслимые поступки. Иногда оно делает человека сильнее, иногда, наоборот, превращает в беспомощное создание. Трудно ответить, является ли это состояние сугубо позитивным или негативным. Однако есть люди, для которых внушение страха - всего лишь профессия. Например, писатели ужастиков. Для них страх - средство заработка, однако рано или поздно они становятся рабами этого чувства и вернуть их к нормальной жизни ой как затруднительно.\nТак вот, надо круче. Надо, чтобы история развивалась динамичнее. Надо, чтобы ответы были ответами, а не началами вопросов с заделом «на будущее». Надо, чтобы песни, звучащие после окончания каждого эпизода, прилагались отдельным диском, так как их и в машину не грех взять. И все эти «надо» – это лишь от авторской обиды. За то, что хочется ставить высокие оценки, за то, что история Алана Вейка полностью заслуживает того, чтобы с ней ознакомились все.                                И да: бойтесь темноты, она коварна!

reviewText:
Alan Wake is ambitious if nothing else. It took the makers years to make (which included many delays), and there is clear evidence throughout the game that it was originally meant to be at least semi-open world rather than sectioned into levels. Once it did come out though, it heralded a new style of narrative with chapters played like episodes of a TV show, replete with visual summaries of the previous episode at the start of each of them. That desire to experiment with narrative in the game is easily the best part, and even though it's very heavily inspired by Stephen King, it's still a very original style for gaming and will keep you playing through even the dullest gameplay portions.

And that's the main problem with Alan Wake, the gameplay. Now, that's not to say it's even that bad, it's actually pretty enjoyable and adds a lot of tension that really helps the game's atmosphere. The game even introduces new and interesting enemies for a while that keep you on your toes! But somewhere around the halfway point the game gets bored with introducing new gameplay elements, and of course shortly after that point you will too. The game really does start to drag towards the end, and if you're anything like me it will feel like a real grind to finish it and see what happens to the story. Aaaand then there's no satisfactory conclusion either. The game wants you to play the episodes that were released as DLC, but due to lukewarm reception (the game already got boring, and the DLC adds nothing while rewarding you with even less substantial story), they got cut short at just the 2. I should mention Alan Wake 2 is rumoured to be in the works, so there is that anyway.

But to cut this short, Alan Wake is absolutely fantastic for half of the game, and then falls short towards the end. Despite this, it's frankly a must play for what it does right, so I recommend it for sure.

reviewText:
Alan Wake is a Portable Electricity Generator simulator released by Remedy in 2012.
During gameplay you will be required to start, repair, and get killed next to various generators scattered throughout the playable world.
Various enemies will hinder your progress to start each generator, and you can hold them off by using flares, your flashlight, or your flashlight and gun.
Once the generator has started it will usually power a lightbulb, which will heal your health and dispell enemies long enough to make your way to the next generator.

90 Volts / 115 Volts

reviewText: Alan Wake takes a lot from John Carpenter's In the Mouth of Madness, which I love. Alan, a horror novel writer, awakens after a car crash while on vacation with his wife unable to remember an entire weeks worth of events. His wife is now missing and his works of fiction have been made a reality in his absence. He must now navigate a small logging town called Bright Falls and survive countless encounters with the Taken (shadowy, derranged campers/woodsmen turned violent) in order to find and rescue his beloved wife.\n\nThis game is episodic so its broken apart nicely and feels like it could very well have been its own hbo or amc miniseries. All in all its been a lot of fun so far. I reccommend buying it if you see it on sale, its worth it.

reviewText:
If you enjoy the Silent Hill games, you will definitely enjoy Alan Wake. I am merely making the Silent Hill reference to show you what a great story-driven and carefully crafted game Alan Wake is. It is certainly not a Silent Hill clone and is very unique.

Clever story, fun combat, and some very tense moments. The atmosphere and story work together perfectly. I couldn't wait to see what was going to happen next, and some parts of the game will really get your heart pumping. I won't spoil anything. I'll just say some of the scenes get really intense. There are a few puzzles thrown into the mix, but they are pretty basic and easy. The story and fun combat is where this game shines.

I will admit that some parts of the game were really hard for me, even on easy mode, but you can get through them with a little learning (learn to find the hidden item caches, look for alternate paths, run instead of fight, etc). I don't fault the game for this because it made me think of alternate solutions and made it feel really satisfying when I finally beat a part of the game that was giving me problems. Don't worry about it too much though. Checkpoints are encountered often so you won't have to replay much if you die.

Picked it up for $5 during a sale, but would have no problem paying the full price. You can easily tell within moments of playing that the creators were passionate about making a great game. It's an awesome game worth playing for people who enjoy adventure/action horror games.

reviewText:
This is one of those rare games where your imagination can be used to massively increase the gaming experience. Some here have described it as playing a Stephen King horror story and I have to agree. If you're a jaded player and go looking for faults, you'll find them in every game including this one, but the story driven gameplay is fantastic. Well that's my opinion.
It is one of the most atmospheric games I've played and ranks in my small personal list of great games.

Play alone, in the dark and with headphones. Engage your imagination and child-like fear of the dark, then feel your skin crawl as you play. Never did a lamp-post look so appealing. Enjoy.

Note: For me, get the original and stick with it because the extra bonus levels and American nightmare just don't cut it at all. They don't have the same well written atmosphere to them and do nothing for the terrific ending of the first game.

During the game listen to Alan Wakes' description of what makes a horror story feel real etc etc. If you get what he's saying then just stop at the end of the first game. When you think about it, it's a truly horrifying ending ;)

reviewText:
If you play games for the game play mechanics, then you might like this title. Alan Wake is a third-person survival horror mystery. The main character is a writer, so he is portrayed as not very athletic. This translates into the feeling of slugish and unresponsive movement. Enemies must first be cleansed of darkness by shining a flashlight on them for varying amounts of time (3-10 seconds). I found this mechanic to be a bit frustrating later in the game. The flashlight also acts as the targeting reticule. There are 5 different guns available: revolver, double-barrel shotgun, pump-action shotgun, hunting rifle and the flare gun. The flare gun acts as a rocket launcher since all of the enemies are weak to light. There are also flashbangs and road flares. Ammo is somewhat scare, and there will be times when the player will be out of ammo if care isn't taken. There is no upgrade system in this game.

If you play games for the storytelling, then you will probably like this title.  The main character and his wife go on vacation to a small pacific northwest town in an attempt to cure his writer's block. I found the characters to be mostly interesting. I also though that the dialog and voice acting were very good.

The design of the world and the characters is very good in my opinion. The lighting is mostly dark, though. There are a few sections of the story that take place during the day, but most of it is during the night.

I was annoyed by the frailty and sluggishness of the main character, and the fact that most of the game takes place at very low light levels. This obviously gave a sense of urgancy to everything, but this changed to annoyance for me towards the later parts of the story. I also foung the game to be more challenging than I would have expected on the lowest difficulty setting.

Overall, I enjoyed my time with this title. Aside from the annoyances, I found the story to be well worth it.

reviewText:
What can I say? This game is an absolute narrative masterpiece. Similar to the movie Inception the game does not make it clear which realities are real, and which are not, who is real, and who is not. Dip and and out of dreams until it is impossible to tell when you are awake. I found it hard to understand who I was even playing as in the game the narrative is that well-spun. Fighting in the dark against torrents of 'taken' farmhands and mechanics is certainly my idea of a good time.

The graphics are amazing in this game, allowing for countless opportunities to take snapshots of the beautiful rural scenery both in light and dark - but even if they weren't, there would still be much to be enjoyed through the narrative that one becomes intrigued and lost in. I cannot overstate enough the narrative genius that is communicated through this game.

There is only one negative that I would have to say about this game, and that is the driving - which can often feel sluggish and untamable. However, this does not in any way detract from the game's overall ability to impress.

I have thoroughly enjoyed this horror, and if anyone knows of any that are similar, please let me know.

10/10 without a doubt.

reviewText: Another lovely game from the developers of Max Payne 1 and 2. The main character is a writer caught up in a thriller story. The story is quite nice and has a good deal of enjoyable foreshadowing, it jumps between nightmare and normalcy throughout the game. It has not, unfortunately, managed to resist the fad of scattering collectibles around and offering achievements for collecting them to pad the time it takes to complete, but it is not a very big problem. The protagonist also suffers from an awful case of butterfingers, consntatly losing your hard-won stuff like stronger flashlights and guns. A solid effort. The PC version has received a fair amount of love from the developers with somewhat cuztomizable graphics, an option to adjust FOV (!) and an option to remove auto aim and mouse acceleration; this is more than what can be said about most AAA titles on the market today.

reviewText:
Alan Wake is a Portable Electricity Generator simulator released by Remedy in 2012.
During gameplay you will be required to start, repair, and get killed next to various generators scattered throughout the playable world.
Various enemies will hinder your progress to start each generator, and you can hold them off by using flares, your flashlight, or your flashlight and gun.
Once the generator has started it will usually power a lightbulb, which will heal your health and dispell enemies long enough to make your way to the next generator.

90 Volts / 115 Volts

reviewText:
Just completed the Alan Wake experience. I say experience because it was an imersion in movie, novel and game.

It places emphasis on the most important thing a lot of games these days are lacking: a good story.

This story was told in a way that spared no expense in quality. From the atmosphere, to the sound track that includes well known artists, to the detail of graphics and textures. The importance of the way light and lighting was used in the graphics and story sets this game apart.

It has well developed characters, stories within stories that aren't boring and epic, well directed cut scenes all set in a picturesque, haunting environment. A mixture of the best bits of Silent Hill, Telltale's Walking Dead, Skyrim and Resident Evil. A brilliant work of art.

I think the only thing that let it down was the marketing and publicity as if it had of been promoted more, I would have got to it sooner.

recommended: "get to the farm". If I hear Alan Wake say "I had to get to the..." one more time!  If you don't think you can overlook the flaws in the gameplay stay away. If you dig the vibe of this game consider it but wait for a good sale. A very cautious recommendation."

reviewText:
Top game! So much immersion in this one. Looking at the graphics (max settings), this game looks incredibly good for the time it was made. This game isn't much about graphics though, it's about telling you a story.
On overall I really liked this game, it was very deep. But playing it for 10 hours straight, I did notice that the combat was pretty flat: it was always the same.. pop off their darkness and shoot them a couple of times and they die. Then you have flares and flashbangs that add a little extra, but that was it. Fortunately enough in the DLC: American Nightmare there's much more weapons. That DLC was also much enjoyable, even though I finished nightmare mode in just 3 hours! It really completes the whole story.. [spoiler alert] Because at the end Alan Wake is still trapped in his darkness, but when you finish American Nightmare you get out of that.

Story: 9/10
Gameplay: 8/10
Graphics: 8/10
Dialogue: 8/10
Extra adds: 7/10 (especially 'Put the lime in the coconut' made me laugh very hard!)

reviewText:
Alan's Wank is the latest game by the developer that brought you the classic racing game ReVolt (Dreamcast version only) and the hugely influential Maximum Carnage that introduced the revolutionary mechanic 'Gullet Time'.

You control Alan Awake -- an award-winning dolphin novelist -- And aim his fleshlight at crows and stuff. WEEEIRD...! The music also adds a lot to the game. Play it loud in stereo, dude! You can buy the music on CD from Nintendo if your Nintendo isn't hooked up to a stereo system. Barry Wheeler remebers music in the old days, but Alan is TRULY with the times (so to speak). His music is great for listening, just beat an episode and listen to the music without the game sound effects. Speaking of sound effects; you'll notice the quality of the echos in the caves and Alan's ape-noises.

Bottom line: Get it now. The graphics are an example of a revolution. Play control is very responsive and monkey-feeling. Alan Stank is TRULY perfect. If you do not get this amazing new generation of dolphin-novelist madness, then you are STUPID. Yes, I know, that's insulting, but it's also the truth. If you are a true video game fan, you will not hesitate in the slightest bit to buy this incredible piece of video game history.

reviewText: This game grabbed me in a way I had forgotten that gaming could grab me. It pulled me into a deep and engaging story. It scared the heck out of me. It made me care about the characters and what would become of them. Much has been said about its developmental change from open world to an episodic structure, but after playing this game through twice now, I wouldn't have it any other way. Also, despite the linearity, the game greatly benefits from this open world engine; on a current gaming system, players can see to lush forests and rustic towns to the horizon. This 'Twin Peaks/American Gothic' presentation is what's so gripping. The game feels like a TV drama, down to the 'previously on Alan Wake' montages and the 'closing credits' music between episodes. So much about this game is obviously the product of love and pure creative passion. Remedy: I wish you'd made Max Payne 3.\n\nTechnically, the engine is tight, finely tuned and runs beautifully on all detail settings. The lighting and related effects are superb. The motion and control are also responsive and smooth. There was only one bug in which all objects but the lights would be rendered, resulting in an almost entirely black screen. This only occurred twice and restarting the game and the chapter fixed the situation. It must be noted that I have completed the game and its DLC three times; the first time was an all night session into mid morning. The game is worth it.

reviewText:
This Game is a carefully crafted masterpiece.
The characters are very well written, the gameplay is unique and challenging. On top of that the player is thrown in a dense and disturbing atmosphere similar to cinematic classics such as The Shining".
There are quite some ironic cultural references as well.
Remedy did a great job by implementing a whole load of details featuring TV-Sequences
hoursPlayed:
and pages of a manuscript you are trapped in.
The succesful fusion of Action and Story makes Alan Wake a more than just enjoyable game.
People looking for a linear single-player shooter or a horror game like Amnesia won't like this game too much.
Story and Gameplay are the keywords to describe the "Alan Wake"-experience."

reviewText: Work Of Art
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Note: This game is polarizing and I will give my best ability to not give an unbiased review.

What this game does right is captivating the audience into playing more. The game is set in an episodic story arc, weird for a video game, but Alan Wake pulls it off. It is not like The Walking Dead Episodic series, but instead each chapter is broken into the episodic format. At the beginning of each episode (excluding episode one) is a recap of the previous episode. If you are like me and you continue to play through the game, then the recap is not really needed, but it does keep the tone of the game. At times these recaps are helpful when it comes to remembering the plot or just returning back to the game. At the end of each episode, the credits roll and a song is playing. Once you skip or let the credits roll, the game will send you to the next episode.

The story overall is fantastic and the game’s writers knew what they wanted for the game. These writers are famous for writing the first two Max Payne games, so the majority of the story is told through Alan Wake, the protagonist, as the narrator. The story is about Alan Wake, a successful writer who suffers from writer’s block. He and his wife, Alice, go to Bright Falls, where they vacation to clear Alan’s mind. Then in their stay, Alice is pulled into the darkness and it is up to Alan to save her. Along the way Alan discovers manuscripts of his work in progress, Departure which tells a chilling story of events, and Alan realizes that whatever is on these pages will happen in the real world. This short summary of what is to come in Alan Wake.

The gameplay is a story of its own. The basic mechanics of Alan Wake are to get from point A to point B with enemies and puzzles to get in the way. Fighting enemies in this game are not in the traditional sense. The theme of Alan Wake is Darkness, and the ironically named Bright Falls is being taken over by the Darkness. The Darkness consumes people and Alan Wake has to shine light from his flashlight on his enemies to clear the Darkness from them before he can shoot and kill them. Not only does Alan Wake fight, but he has a dodging mechanic to where he ducks and weaves from his enemies that either attack or throw tools at him. This feature, like Max Payne’s shoot dodge, is used a lot to avoid enemies.

Now what this game does poorly is its character expression during cut scenes. The character development is awesome and the models are great, but when the characters speak, their lips and face are awkward enough to question the games programming, but it is not so bad that it takes away from the experience of the game. Another complaint is the PC port has a couple of glitches when I played, but Remedy remedied that (lol). Also the gameplay to a certain degree is a bit tedious. The running from point A to point B while doing rendered the same actions over and over is a little bit redundant at times, but there is enough variety in between these segments to make it not boring. Ultimately, the story is what saved Alan Wake from being a generic third person game to being a great experience overall. The story is what keeps you playing; the story is what makes you care for the characters; the story is what drives the gameplay home. You cannot go wrong with purchasing this game.



Scale:
Story 10/10
*Writing, Pacing, and Voice acting
Gameplay: 8/10
*Fun, but redundant to a point
Graphics 9/10
*Fantastic landscapes and models, but glitches in talking and walking.
Replay value: 8/10
*Great, like watching a movie, and there are collectables.
Effort: 9/10
*The Designers took 5 years to make this, but the glitches is what makes it a 9.
_____________________________________________________________________________________
Overall: 9
*Rating Scale is based on the average of the 5 main categories and round to the nearest number.
Thank You for reading first effortful review. Please let me know how I did.

reviewText:
A real review.

The missing tag for Alan Wake in it's discription is 'story driven'. Alan Wake is a story driven game. There are many good things about this game but it is the story that will compel you to finish it.

The horror aspect is mixed into the gameplay and it works at the start as you nervously walk through a forest at night with the feeling you are being chased by axe weilding country folk. As the story progesses you will master the combat style of duelwielding a flash light and a gun to kill the 'darkness'. Once mastered you find yourself collecting heaps of ammo, flares, flashbangs etc, so much so that no matter what object the 'darkness' chooses to posses you will have more than enough to defend yourself and loosing some of that horror in the process.

The gameplay is different than anything else i have played which straight away makes it fun. Visually, the world you are in is beautiful, dark, dangerous and mysterious. The sound is also very good. The game has a great atmosphere. But...

The cutscenes and story are so so so much better than the level design and gameplay that you will reach a cutscene, learn more of this increasingly interesting and captivating story, you will be all excited to find out more when Alan somehow manages to fall back into a forest. A dark forest. You finally get to the next cutscene, awesome, more story but then Alan slips and falls into the forest. Cutscene, forest, cutscene, another ****ing forest. That is how i felt playing this game by the end. I was racing through the level to get to the next part in the story. The horror gameplay really takes a back seat maybe half way through the game.

But the story is that good that you will want to keep playing. One last thing, there is one type of enemy that you come across , little spoiler...

It is so annoying, runs super fast so you cant shine your flashlight on it until it attacks you. It runs all around so you dont know from which direction will it jump out of the darkness, sounds scary but it isn't. It takes so long to try attack you that you have to stand there for a few minutes waiting. It's frustrating. You will know this enemy as soon as you see him. If he takes too long to attck you just run to the next checkpoint and he will dissapear. Really stupid character.

All in all, if you want an action game with non repetitve gameplay this game is NOT for you! If you want something different with a great story this game IS FOR YOU!

I liked it accept for that one type of enemy, so stupid, shouldn't be in the game.

reviewText: This game I had to get to grips with for it to grow on me. First I was recommended to try this game, and read many positive reviews so I thought this ought to be a good game. The first hour of playing I was thinking to myself, how on earth everybody loves this game so much. It was super linear, cinematics were not that convincing, voice acting was not superior, blocky geometry etc. The beginning was a bit of a let down for me. But man this game gets going like a virtual twin peaks once you perservere with it. I think my initial expectations were different since I had followed this game somewhat during it's development around 2006-2007 and back then it was supposed to be an open world game. But once this game gets going the linearity is a non issue for me anymore. On the contrary it's almost mandatory to keep the pacing of the game and it's story tight. Story and locations are very Twin Peaks like. This game will not be easy to understand because it was supposed to continue, so you have unanswered questions left. But so was twin peaks also, a lot of weird stuff just remained weird and that contributed to it's bizarre atmosphere that really was it's selling points.\n\nIf you like bizarre suspenceful games, this should do it for you. It is a well made game. Even it does show signs of aging but gracefully so. Oh, and the voice acting that was a bit of a let down in the beginning for me, does improve and reaches a point where the story is told believably and fluently. I kind of wish Remedy would return to this and finish it off open world style one day. Great game even with it's change of direction and style from it's beginnings. And boy does this game have tons of surprises for a Remedy gaming fan..

This was no Max Payne, I'm afraid. Worth what I paid, but just barely.

reviewText:
Just completed the Alan Wake experience. I say experience because it was an imersion in movie, novel and game.

It places emphasis on the most important thing a lot of games these days are lacking: a good story.

This story was told in a way that spared no expense in quality. From the atmosphere, to the sound track that includes well known artists, to the detail of graphics and textures. The importance of the way light and lighting was used in the graphics and story sets this game apart.

It has well developed characters, stories within stories that aren't boring and epic, well directed cut scenes all set in a picturesque, haunting environment. A mixture of the best bits of Silent Hill, Telltale's Walking Dead, Skyrim and Resident Evil. A brilliant work of art.

I think the only thing that let it down was the marketing and publicity as if it had of been promoted more, I would have got to it sooner.

reviewText:
A fresh take on the Survival Horror Genre.
A psychological manipulator that has wit, innovation and integrity.

Play as writer Alan Wake when he awakens in a world full of mystery and full of darkness.
Travel through wicked territories and face terrifying creatures in order to rescue your girlfriend from the demonic forces.

Light is your only friend and is the only thing that can help you on your journey. In order to cause damage to any demon you must first purge them with light to break down their protective barrier. Use a flashlight, street lamp, torch, explosive barrel - any resource available to illuminate the darkness and defeat the demons.

10/10 - Highly recommended to fans of the Survival Horror Genre.

reviewText:
Note: This game is polarizing and I will give my best ability to not give an unbiased review.

What this game does right is captivating the audience into playing more. The game is set in an episodic story arc, weird for a video game, but Alan Wake pulls it off. It is not like The Walking Dead Episodic series, but instead each chapter is broken into the episodic format. At the beginning of each episode (excluding episode one) is a recap of the previous episode. If you are like me and you continue to play through the game, then the recap is not really needed, but it does keep the tone of the game. At times these recaps are helpful when it comes to remembering the plot or just returning back to the game. At the end of each episode, the credits roll and a song is playing. Once you skip or let the credits roll, the game will send you to the next episode.

The story overall is fantastic and the game’s writers knew what they wanted for the game. These writers are famous for writing the first two Max Payne games, so the majority of the story is told through Alan Wake, the protagonist, as the narrator. The story is about Alan Wake, a successful writer who suffers from writer’s block. He and his wife, Alice, go to Bright Falls, where they vacation to clear Alan’s mind. Then in their stay, Alice is pulled into the darkness and it is up to Alan to save her. Along the way Alan discovers manuscripts of his work in progress, Departure which tells a chilling story of events, and Alan realizes that whatever is on these pages will happen in the real world. This short summary of what is to come in Alan Wake.

The gameplay is a story of its own. The basic mechanics of Alan Wake are to get from point A to point B with enemies and puzzles to get in the way. Fighting enemies in this game are not in the traditional sense. The theme of Alan Wake is Darkness, and the ironically named Bright Falls is being taken over by the Darkness. The Darkness consumes people and Alan Wake has to shine light from his flashlight on his enemies to clear the Darkness from them before he can shoot and kill them. Not only does Alan Wake fight, but he has a dodging mechanic to where he ducks and weaves from his enemies that either attack or throw tools at him. This feature, like Max Payne’s shoot dodge, is used a lot to avoid enemies.

Now what this game does poorly is its character expression during cut scenes. The character development is awesome and the models are great, but when the characters speak, their lips and face are awkward enough to question the games programming, but it is not so bad that it takes away from the experience of the game. Another complaint is the PC port has a couple of glitches when I played, but Remedy remedied that (lol). Also the gameplay to a certain degree is a bit tedious. The running from point A to point B while doing rendered the same actions over and over is a little bit redundant at times, but there is enough variety in between these segments to make it not boring. Ultimately, the story is what saved Alan Wake from being a generic third person game to being a great experience overall. The story is what keeps you playing; the story is what makes you care for the characters; the story is what drives the gameplay home. You cannot go wrong with purchasing this game.



Scale:
Story 10/10
*Writing, Pacing, and Voice acting
Gameplay: 8/10
*Fun, but redundant to a point
Graphics 9/10
*Fantastic landscapes and models, but glitches in talking and walking.
Replay value: 8/10
*Great, like watching a movie, and there are collectables.
Effort: 9/10
*The Designers took 5 years to make this, but the glitches is what makes it a 9.
_____________________________________________________________________________________
Overall: 9
*Rating Scale is based on the average of the 5 main categories and round to the nearest number.
Thank You for reading first effortful review. Please let me know how I did.

reviewText:
Alan Wake is one of those games that really surprised me of how good atmosphere can really be!
It's about a writer dude that comes to Bright Falls with his wife to get rid of his writers blockage and to get some hot wifey action on a lake in a boat (but they never tell you that)..

Ofcourse, ♥♥♥♥ hit the fan and some misterios, unexplained events happen, his wife is missing, everyone think he killed her, but few townsfolk actually have some hints on what is going on there.. As the story develops, you learn about similar events that happen before and about Alan's troublesome past..

Game is action/adventure survival, in third person view that doesn't have that much adventure puzzles in it, it's more of enjoying the story as it builds up from chapter to chapter with great cut scenes that are directly in the game..

Sometimes you really can't tell if Alan is crazy, imagining things or things he is going through are actually real! Game is divided in 6 chapters and 2 special features that furter explains the story behind Bright Falls and bla bla spoilers..

PRO
- incredible atmosphere, heavily influenced by Twilight Zone, one of the best TV psychological horror show..
- Graphics and scenery, game is spread over a town Bright Falls, mountain, cabin on the lake, roads, many awesome places, a lodge, old sawmill, farm etc.
- gameplay is smooth and enticing, story is very well paced and delivered and for once, there are not many logical errors..
- sounds and music are very good made, music get little wilder when you fight enemies, and all that clasic ♥♥♥♥ hehe
- weapons and stuff are very well made, there are few clasic weapons like pistol, shotty, flare gun, flares, and as you play, you really don't need much to think about saving ammo, there are plenty (until you play on hard or nightmare mode :)

CONS
- controls are somewhat slow" i.e. Alan needs few steps to stop or slow down

reviewText:
Finished, but only because of the story. It's actually quite good. As many have said, it's like Stephen King meets Twin Peaks. I can even overlook the uncanny valley mannequins in the cut scenes with weird sync issues between their speech and how their mouths move.

The main problem is that the story is trapped inside an unremarkable game. I understand that Alan is a writer not a fighter. (And sadly not much of a runner either; is he really that out of shape?) So why build a game around him where he constantly has to shoot things to stay alive? The flashlight is cool. The gun play is mediocre at best and gets quickly repetitive.

SPOILER: Ninety-percent of Episode Six is a long drive/run through the woods at night with enemies jumping you every few minutes until you reach the story's resolution. They should have made Episode Five twenty minutes longer and wrapped it up as there is no more story between the end of it and finally reaching the lake in Ep Six.

I didn't bother with the DLC, and based on what I've read of the follow-on-not-sequel American Nightmare, I'm going to skip it too.

If I was re-imagining this game from a different angle I'd have it be a Telltale game with branching narrative and the flashlight would be your primary weapon for killing the Taken. That seems like a far better fit instead of confining a story that could have been even more detailed inside a lame shooter.

Rating: 6/10
Recommended if you are big fan of horror fiction as that's the only thing it has going for it.

reviewText:
Alan Wake is a truly underrated and sadly ignored game which did not receive the kind of attention it deserves. This game is not perfect, but it still does most everything right to the smallest detail, in the most original and creative of ways.

First off, the atmosphere is absurdly engaging, realistic, absorbing, and scary. The lighting engine especially in this game is better than any game I've seen so far. Which makes sense, considering how essential the lighting mechanics are for this game.

What people say is correct - it is literally like playing through/experiencing a Stephen King novel. It is wonderfully cinematographic, during gameplay and in the cutscenes. Plus the voice acting is top notch, perfect attention was given to sound details and animations, and the story is really well paced. The story and the game's atmosphere keeps you on your toes the entire time, with unpredictable plot progression and developments, and a twisting, deep, surprise-filled story.

Speaking of tension, this is one of the few games that actually makes you address each battle scenario strategically (A few others being Bioshock, Borderlands, etc.). You are so scarce on ammo and flashlight batteries throughout most of the game, that you start to bug out when you are running out of ammo, and the enemies keep spawning anyway, as if they thought you were Rambo or something. You scour every area of the map looking for any bits of ammo you can find. Each enemy takes so much work to kill that it can easily get overwhelming and you can quickly use up your ammo.

The game implements some pretty crafty platforming and environmental puzzles, particularly in the The Writer DLC. Albeit short, I greatly enjoyed that DLC  because it was just pure creativity, from beginning to end. I did not enjoy the The Signal DLC as much, but it was still good. That one felt too repetitive and eventually got quite frustrating, but it still had creative content and impressive technical feats.

You get plenty of gametime out of this game - 11-14 hours for the main story alone. And then 1.5 hours for each of the DLC, and also however much time goes into finding all the hidden objects spread throughout the levels, if you are into that kind of thing.

So in summary, with a fantastic, original, well-paced, complex, non-cliche and creative story, a very impressive game engine that looks absolutely gorgeous a LOT of the time (I took 175 screenshots in my single playthrough. :D), solid shooting mechanics, nice attention to detail, a consistently frightening and tense environment, and excellent level design, this is a game I would HIGHLY recommend, to anyone who feels they can handle a psychological horror game of this degree.

reviewText:
A real review.

The missing tag for Alan Wake in it's discription is 'story driven'. Alan Wake is a story driven game. There are many good things about this game but it is the story that will compel you to finish it.

The horror aspect is mixed into the gameplay and it works at the start as you nervously walk through a forest at night with the feeling you are being chased by axe weilding country folk. As the story progesses you will master the combat style of duelwielding a flash light and a gun to kill the 'darkness'. Once mastered you find yourself collecting heaps of ammo, flares, flashbangs etc, so much so that no matter what object the 'darkness' chooses to posses you will have more than enough to defend yourself and loosing some of that horror in the process.

The gameplay is different than anything else i have played which straight away makes it fun. Visually, the world you are in is beautiful, dark, dangerous and mysterious. The sound is also very good. The game has a great atmosphere. But...

The cutscenes and story are so so so much better than the level design and gameplay that you will reach a cutscene, learn more of this increasingly interesting and captivating story, you will be all excited to find out more when Alan somehow manages to fall back into a forest. A dark forest. You finally get to the next cutscene, awesome, more story but then Alan slips and falls into the forest. Cutscene, forest, cutscene, another ****ing forest. That is how i felt playing this game by the end. I was racing through the level to get to the next part in the story. The horror gameplay really takes a back seat maybe half way through the game.

But the story is that good that you will want to keep playing. One last thing, there is one type of enemy that you come across , little spoiler...

It is so annoying, runs super fast so you cant shine your flashlight on it until it attacks you. It runs all around so you dont know from which direction will it jump out of the darkness, sounds scary but it isn't. It takes so long to try attack you that you have to stand there for a few minutes waiting. It's frustrating. You will know this enemy as soon as you see him. If he takes too long to attck you just run to the next checkpoint and he will dissapear. Really stupid character.

All in all, if you want an action game with non repetitve gameplay this game is NOT for you! If you want something different with a great story this game IS FOR YOU!

I liked it accept for that one type of enemy, so stupid, shouldn't be in the game.
