reviewText:
Simply put, Alan Wake plays like a Stephen King novel turned into a TV miniseries turned into a videogame. This is intentional by Remedy and this narrative complexity is one of the game’s strengths.

Remedy has woven a very complex story into Alan Wake and that’s really half of the reason to play this game. The main story, told in episodes like a TV series, is about Alan piecing together what’s happened in his missing week while the ever-present darkness corrupts the townspeople and relentlessly pursues him. However during that missing week, Alan apparently wrote a pre-cognitive novel about the very events that are happening to him, because as you play you keep finding manuscript pages that he wrote and that describe everything that subsequently happens to him. These are a lot of fun to hunt out and collect because they explain the rather fragmented story and make you feel just as desperate and paranoid as Alan—groping in the dark for answers, desperate that the next chapter page will reveal the truth he needs.

Blood and gore are so downplayed in Alan Wake as to be next to nonexistent. There are no chainsaw wielding psychopaths or bloodthirsty monsters—just the creeping darkness, and the unsettling things it does to the citizens of Bright Falls. People go missing in the woods and nobody sees this as unusual; later, when you’re lost in the woods, these missing people come after you, shrouded in oily shadows and out to gut you with whatever bladed implement they have handy.

Alan is a writer, not a warrior, but he has his trusty flashlight and an assortment of small arms to beat back the Taken, as the infected townspeople are called. First you must aim Alan’s light at an enemy and boost its output to burn away the darkness, and then finish off the Taken with a few shots from your pistol or shotgun. It might sound repetitive but with multiple Taken emerging from the shadows and your flashlight dwindling, it can get pretty hectic as you juggle reloading your tiny snub-nose and popping fresh batteries into your light, all while running away from and dodging attacks. Later on you can get better lights and weapons, including flares to give you breathing room and flash bang grenades to clear an area, but ammo is usually scarce and you must balance exploration with your limited reserves.

Everything in the PC version is essentially the same as the Xbox 360 version. Alan Wake is one of the best converted, least buggy PC ports I have played in a long time. The quirky characters and stark daylight sequences might temporarily pull you out of the terror, but the memories of wandering around in the woods, hounded by eldritch shadows, will haunt your nightmares for months to come.

reviewText:
Note: This game is polarizing and I will give my best ability to not give an unbiased review.

What this game does right is captivating the audience into playing more. The game is set in an episodic story arc, weird for a video game, but Alan Wake pulls it off. It is not like The Walking Dead Episodic series, but instead each chapter is broken into the episodic format. At the beginning of each episode (excluding episode one) is a recap of the previous episode. If you are like me and you continue to play through the game, then the recap is not really needed, but it does keep the tone of the game. At times these recaps are helpful when it comes to remembering the plot or just returning back to the game. At the end of each episode, the credits roll and a song is playing. Once you skip or let the credits roll, the game will send you to the next episode.

The story overall is fantastic and the game’s writers knew what they wanted for the game. These writers are famous for writing the first two Max Payne games, so the majority of the story is told through Alan Wake, the protagonist, as the narrator. The story is about Alan Wake, a successful writer who suffers from writer’s block. He and his wife, Alice, go to Bright Falls, where they vacation to clear Alan’s mind. Then in their stay, Alice is pulled into the darkness and it is up to Alan to save her. Along the way Alan discovers manuscripts of his work in progress, Departure which tells a chilling story of events, and Alan realizes that whatever is on these pages will happen in the real world. This short summary of what is to come in Alan Wake.

The gameplay is a story of its own. The basic mechanics of Alan Wake are to get from point A to point B with enemies and puzzles to get in the way. Fighting enemies in this game are not in the traditional sense. The theme of Alan Wake is Darkness, and the ironically named Bright Falls is being taken over by the Darkness. The Darkness consumes people and Alan Wake has to shine light from his flashlight on his enemies to clear the Darkness from them before he can shoot and kill them. Not only does Alan Wake fight, but he has a dodging mechanic to where he ducks and weaves from his enemies that either attack or throw tools at him. This feature, like Max Payne’s shoot dodge, is used a lot to avoid enemies.

Now what this game does poorly is its character expression during cut scenes. The character development is awesome and the models are great, but when the characters speak, their lips and face are awkward enough to question the games programming, but it is not so bad that it takes away from the experience of the game. Another complaint is the PC port has a couple of glitches when I played, but Remedy remedied that (lol). Also the gameplay to a certain degree is a bit tedious. The running from point A to point B while doing rendered the same actions over and over is a little bit redundant at times, but there is enough variety in between these segments to make it not boring. Ultimately, the story is what saved Alan Wake from being a generic third person game to being a great experience overall. The story is what keeps you playing; the story is what makes you care for the characters; the story is what drives the gameplay home. You cannot go wrong with purchasing this game.



Scale:
Story 10/10
*Writing, Pacing, and Voice acting
Gameplay: 8/10
*Fun, but redundant to a point
Graphics 9/10
*Fantastic landscapes and models, but glitches in talking and walking.
Replay value: 8/10
*Great, like watching a movie, and there are collectables.
Effort: 9/10
*The Designers took 5 years to make this, but the glitches is what makes it a 9.
_____________________________________________________________________________________
Overall: 9
*Rating Scale is based on the average of the 5 main categories and round to the nearest number.
Thank You for reading first effortful review. Please let me know how I did.

reviewText: This game I had to get to grips with for it to grow on me. First I was recommended to try this game, and read many positive reviews so I thought this ought to be a good game. The first hour of playing I was thinking to myself, how on earth everybody loves this game so much. It was super linear, cinematics were not that convincing, voice acting was not superior, blocky geometry etc. The beginning was a bit of a let down for me. But man this game gets going like a virtual twin peaks once you perservere with it. I think my initial expectations were different since I had followed this game somewhat during it's development around 2006-2007 and back then it was supposed to be an open world game. But once this game gets going the linearity is a non issue for me anymore. On the contrary it's almost mandatory to keep the pacing of the game and it's story tight. Story and locations are very Twin Peaks like. This game will not be easy to understand because it was supposed to continue, so you have unanswered questions left. But so was twin peaks also, a lot of weird stuff just remained weird and that contributed to it's bizarre atmosphere that really was it's selling points.\n\nIf you like bizarre suspenceful games, this should do it for you. It is a well made game. Even it does show signs of aging but gracefully so. Oh, and the voice acting that was a bit of a let down in the beginning for me, does improve and reaches a point where the story is told believably and fluently. I kind of wish Remedy would return to this and finish it off open world style one day. Great game even with it's change of direction and style from it's beginnings. And boy does this game have tons of surprises for a Remedy gaming fan..

reviewText: This game is such an underrated gem. Nowadays its really hard to find game with good characters, solid storyline (without big holes in narrating), and unique combat system. Alan Wake got all this qualities. Probably combat system is the main feature of Alan Wake. Using flashlight on enemies and only after that shoot them makes this game real survival horror (specially when you are against few enemies). Variety of light weapon is impressing. Alan got different models of flashlights, flash grenades, flyers and etc. but at the same time only one revolver and and couple hunt rifles (proly i might forgot something  ᘳ º  ͜ʖ º ᘰ ). Thing that you dont have advanced military guns (like M4s or AKs) is also a great plus for survival horror game. The second best part of this game is a storyline. Hands down, Sam Lake and Ilkka Villi made a great job to create tension plot with cool and unique characters and well-written dialogues between them. Also pages that you can find all over the game explain big part of the plot and make dark'n'evil atmosphere. This game really held me till its end and truly recommend to everybody who did not try this game still. Regrettably this game was a victim of weird Microsoft policy. It was Xbox 360 exclusive for 2 years. In 2012 it finally came out on PC and developers were really impressed by the sales. Despite that whole sales numbers were low... That's one of the reasons why now we see Quantum break and not Allan Wake 2. P.S. After Alan Wake i have no doubts that Sam Lake is one my favourite writers in game industry.  P.P.S. Looking forward to Quantum Break. P.P.P.S. If you just like me are Shinji Mikami fan and you love Resident Evil series and Evil Within you must buy Alan Wake! └[◔.◔]┘

reviewText:
What is Alan Wake? Summed up: Luigi's Mansion meets Twin Peaks meets Deadly Premonition and with a small serving of early '90s slasher/action flick on the side.

For some of the flaws and missteps it takes, Alan Wake is an enjoyable experience, especially for those with a penchant for creative writing. The titular character, Alan, acts as an avatar of sorts for writers and players and for those inclined, both. He takes a vacation in the sleepy town of Bright Falls, located somewhere in the state of Washington. It is here he finds out - rather harshly - that there are dark forces at work, and with it, unveiling a mystery that engulfs the town.

Don't be fooled, however; this is not a traditional horror game. It has more in common with action-adventure games such as Uncharted and Alone in the Dark 2 than it does with more cerebral games like Silent Hill and Sanitarium. The game plays with a behind the shoulder perspective and your crosshair, so to speak, is provided by a flashlight. Even so, the game controls rather well and Alan's movements and responsive and crisp. There are a few parts where the rather solid movement can make jumping from one platform to the next a little cumbersome, but those are a minor gripe. As for the graphics, they do the job. Often times, you can notice artifacts or little quirks, such as questionable facial animations, but if Fallout 4 can get a free pass for that, so can Alan Wake.

The game's biggest flaw (outside of icy driving controls) is the fact that you cannot explore the town of Bright Falls, as the game is incredibly linear in its direction. You cannot hang out at a local joint like you can in Deadly Premonition or talk to random strangers and get a feel for the town. The reason why I note this is that the characters and dialogue, and by extension writing, are all quite wonderful. All the characters are vibrants with their quirks and personalities. A no-nonsense sheriff, a trigger-happy agent, a disturbingly unfettered doctor, they all stand out vividly. The gameplay itself is nothing to write home about, but it keeps you on your toes and some might find it repetitive at times. But the scenery and massive levels are more than enough to keep you engaged.

[On that note, getting the game with the DLC is highly recommended. You get two full-length episodes (~2 hours of gameplay) that continue the story straight from the ending. They are quite fantastic and switch up the formula nicely.]

Oh, and the soundtrack? ♥♥♥♥ing incredible.

Conclusion: Get the game when it's on sale, you won't regret it.

8/10.

reviewText:
This game is so great. And, it´s the first Horrorgame i ever played where the Story is more than: kill all the zombies by shooting tons of ammo into them. After a while, the world becomes boring, because the most time you play in a forest. But there are some really cool areas like the hospital for artists, a silver mine and more.

The Story can be sometimes distracting, because you won´t get within the first two hours if it´s a dream or reality. Or if you are under shock and imagine all this (i´m in act 4 and i still don´t know this).

The fighting system is innovative and just...perfect. Instead of shooting everything you have in Zombies, you have to get rid of the part of the darkness, which is protecting them and then to shoot them. The Handflares and Flashbangs are a very good tool to get out of conflicts with 4 or more enemys. And they are really needed, they are not something that makes you life easier, it´s essential.

The enemys are very cool too. There are 4 basic types of them: the normal ones, the big ones, the ones with the special abilitys and the Bossfights (they are so freaking epic, it´s worth to buy the game just for the bossfights).


It´s worth it´s money, and while the summer sale it´s a must-have. Or you can buy it in a keyshop (buying keys there is 100% legal, just selling them not (at least in Germany, i don´t know how it´s in Asia, USA etc.) for just 5€).

AND NOW GO AND BUY THIS GAME!!!

reviewText:
Pros:
+ Revolutionary graphical performance. There are other games out there that are visually just as realistic, but they require a much more powerful hardware to run the game.
+ Beautiful rich environment. The creators have put a lot of effort in making the scenery look true to life.
+ The atmosphere is like out of a Stephen King movie. The environment is gloomy, dreadful, with hints of gothic.
+ The setting might resemble Silent Hill. As the lake takes on darker and darker dimensions you get suggestions to Lovecraftian cosmic horror.
+ Enemies are dreadful.
+ The narrator's approach makes it easy to go into the character.
+ Memorable and interesting npc's.
+ Original approach to fighting (flashlight, light overall).
+ Best map markers I've seen. It's as if there's an invisible dotted line all along your path. You never get lost.

Cons:

- Movement, though not bad, could have been even better. Especially jumpting from object to object took unnecsessary effort
and precision.

Conclusion:
It's one of the most dreaded games I've played and a remarkable stepping stone in contemporary horror. The enemies seemed very scary in their simplicity and the battles turned out to be a real challenge. I really felt like I got a quality experience from playing it.

reviewText:
Alan Wake is one of those games that you remember and enjoy because of the writing, the characters, the environment and the attention to detail. Remedy really nailed it with this one, I mean, four years later, the mountains, trees, grass, clothing, all of it looks outstanding with the texturing. The only objects that are outstandishly low res are books and readable stuff, like newspapers, which is ironic to me considering who the protagonist is, a writer.

Anyway, the game boasts a wild premise, Alan Wake, a bestselling author is on vacation with his wife in the gorgeous Pacific north-west. They rent a cabin on a lake in a mysterious town, Bright Falls, and, essentially, a dark essense exists that wishes to exploit Alan Wake. So when Alan isn't looking, his wife falls into the lake by unusual circumstances. Despite Alan's efforts of jumping to help her, the next thing he remembers is waking up a week later in a car wreck. This is where the game gets interesting.

Alan ends up learning how to fight the darkness, also known as the taken. Using flashlights, revolvers, pump shotguns, and hunting rifles. And the gunplay has Remedy written all over it, very cinematic and stylish with diving and avoiding axe and chainsaw, weilding taken. They're frightening, because some of them happen to be people you'd met earlier and disappeared under strange circumstances.

Sam Lake, the head writer at Remedy, deserves all the credit for the direction which is gorgeous, cinematic and well edited. Plus, once you meet more characters, the more interesting the game gets. Without spoiling anything, just prepare for the Eye of Mordor.

10/10
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
HEY GUYS!  I'm just like Stephen King and Dean Koontz!  I mean, I write scary stories, I like to live in small quirky towns in the middle of BFE North East, and creepy ♥♥♥♥ happens to me all the time!  See, just like Stephen King and Dean Koontz!

Don't get me wrong, Alan Wake's all right.  He's just a little heavy on the reference dropping.  If you can get past that, you can get your self a Stephen Koontz esque story that's a bit creepy and overall pretty interesting.  There's nothing too exciting here mechanics wise (KINDA LIKE A DEAN KOONTZ NOVEL AMIRITE?) but let's face it; you're really just here for the story and movie like experience.

In small doses, the 'haha, i'm a troubled writer' schtick doesn't get too thick.  Thankfully, it's laid out in a episodic format which means it's in nice digestible chunks.  Something that Stephen King's novels could use sometimes.  Play this one episode at a time, with your lights off, and it'll be more satisfying than how the Dark Tower played out!

reviewText:
Wakey wakey Alaaaan. This game has a dark, eerie setting that predominantly takes place in a forest surrounding Cauldron Lake where you come across an evil force known as the Taken. This evil can possess both human beings and inanimate objects in a bid to put Alan to sleep, for good. Thankfully, one of Alan's weapons is a torch light, which literally burns the darkness layer protecting the possessed. Once this layer is burned, then it's weapons free till the assailant fades to nothing.

The AI is very good. They'll come at you in numbers, throw weapons at you, spread out and try to flank you and even call in the heavies that can take twice [if not more] the damage. You can try dodging their attacks or run away, though you will not get far at all - they will catch you and hurt you plenty. SO! That leaves you with an offensive defense option - FIGHT. Other than your torch, you have an arsenal of weapons such as a revolver, shotgun and hunting rifle as well as tactical equipment such as flares and flash bangs. Not to mention the flare gun. Choose however you want to attack. Ammo is readily available [I played Normal game mode]. There are no med packs and your health bar renegrates slowly. So if you're not careful with your six, you could be in trouble. Finally, you have some safe havens, such as a lit lamp post to catch your breath.

The graphics are fantastic. The setting is beautiful. The lighting is very good, though can hurt the eye so you may need to turn that brightness down or play in a well lit room. Although, I would highly recommend playing in the dark with the headphones on. Huge emphasis on the story and is an interesting story. Definitely has that Japanese horror feel to it. It did feel as though the developers dragged on a bit with the gameplay to prolong the game, but I think the story covered it well. A must play. 9/10.

reviewText:
What an experience! The level of quality and detail that have gone into this game is phenomenal.

Everything from the detailed worlds, fantastic story telling and haunting gameplay make this a must own for anyone.

Set in a dream in a dream (I think? Inception much?), Alan Wake transports the player into the shoes of Alan Wake, a writer who is struggling to write his next novel. As you play through the game, you come to find the pages of the book Alan has yet to write. Some foretell events still to come while others recount ecperiences past. With the detailed world and well written plot, it's easy to lose yourself in the story (I played it until 2am not noticing the time).

To anyone reading this, just buy the game. It's worth every penny.

reviewText: A fairly underestimated and undiscovered gem, this game follows the story of Alan Wake, an American writer with writer's block and terrifying nightmares. The game has a few downsides, such as a slightly inaccurate combat system and sometimes overly strong enemies. However, if you see this game through despite the lacking combat, it is a definite winner. A simply gorgeous setting in Bright Falls, fluent movements, not a single loading screen while entering homes and an utterly scary story and you have yourself a rock-solid game. Worth every penny.

reviewText: This is a vaguely linear action story. Keeping in mind that the creators are more telling a story than putting you into a RPG will allow you to really enjoy this game. The pacing is good and the story in interesting, the combat is actually fun at times too.

reviewText:
Alan Wake is a mystery wrapped inside an enigma. Nothing else. If you try to make sense of all this, then you are certainly a brave one.

The story, really well written I must say, is heavily inspired by Stephen King, H.P. Lovecraft and such. It does not have the crude horror of Stephen King, but it has the darkness. It does not have the overworldly presence of the Lovecraftian stories, but it has the unexplainable, the evil. Story driven to the core, Alan Wake will make you think twice before going in the dark (even if there isn't a single moment of true horror in my opinion). It's not about the horror really, it's about the darkness. You need to find out what lies in this darkness, what can be found and what should not be found.

Will you be able to kill what you can't see?

Alan Wake is a serious 9/10.

reviewText:
Boy, I enjoyed this one.
Mechanically speaking, it gets old after a while, but still, it deserves a mention for the clever devices that makes you use to kill your enemies; those shadowy figures that run after you while brandishing chainsaws/axes/scalpels, etc.. that can only be hurt after being hit by a source of light. Scary. It makes for some serious heart-pounding moments while you try to catch your bearings, trying to put new batteries in your flashlight while keeping at bay three of those murderous thugs.
Sometimes the best things is just to run for your life.

It has a nice story too, that you have to piece together while playing, all shown in an episodic format, à la TV show, kinda like Lost.

Thumbs up!

reviewText:
Stephen King once wrote that “Nightmares exist outside of logic, and there’s little fun to be had in explanations; they’re antithetical to the poetry of fear.”

Alan Wake, a survival horror game developed by Remedy Entertainment and published by Microsoft Game Studios. You are Alan Wake a best selling thriller novelist trapped in a horror story he wrote which has to come to life and has taken his wife. The game is heavily inspired by thriller which draws concepts from the T.V show Twin Peaks and draws inspiration from the works of Stephen King!

As Alan Wake you must battle through the night to fight the Taken, a darkness that takes over living things and brings life to inanimate objects while trying to find yourself and your wife, which the darkness has taken. Gameplay is in third person and the primary weapon used in the game is light (Flashlight, Flares, flareguns, environmental lighting, flashbangs) as well as guns.  Fighting through lush green national parks and into the town of Bright Falls, Washington the atmosphere psychologically engulfs you, waking up from this nightmare is not an option!

Pros:
-The use of light as a weapon
-A great story, short but sweet will really leave you with a Wow

amazing!"

-Narration really makes it easy to understand whats really going on.

reviewText:
Amazing flare simulator with a genuinely interesting story and a very nice atmoshpere.
Action parts are perhaps too numerous and too mechanically simple. The last new enemy and last new weapons are introduced about 3 hours into the game and after that gameplay formula doesn't change for another 8-10 hours, which makes the game a bit of a drag at times. Burning the same zombie guys again and again and again is only entertaining for so long.
Worth playing if you enjoy a good narrative and are willing to deal with less than stellar gameplay.
I liked it enuff to write a review, so that's definitely something.
Probably best consumed in small doses though - an episode a day or so.

reviewText:
HEY GUYS!  I'm just like Stephen King and Dean Koontz!  I mean, I write scary stories, I like to live in small quirky towns in the middle of BFE North East, and creepy ♥♥♥♥ happens to me all the time!  See, just like Stephen King and Dean Koontz!

Don't get me wrong, Alan Wake's all right.  He's just a little heavy on the reference dropping.  If you can get past that, you can get your self a Stephen Koontz esque story that's a bit creepy and overall pretty interesting.  There's nothing too exciting here mechanics wise (KINDA LIKE A DEAN KOONTZ NOVEL AMIRITE?) but let's face it; you're really just here for the story and movie like experience.

In small doses, the 'haha, i'm a troubled writer' schtick doesn't get too thick.  Thankfully, it's laid out in a episodic format which means it's in nice digestible chunks.  Something that Stephen King's novels could use sometimes.  Play this one episode at a time, with your lights off, and it'll be more satisfying than how the Dark Tower played out!

reviewText:
Simply one of the best horror/survival/action/adventure games I've played since Silent Hill 2.  You play the role of Alan Wake, an author on a vacation with his wife to unwind in a small lakeside town.  What follows is a rollercoaster ride of confusion, realization, depression, and redemption.
+Beautiful and surreal loactions that breath new life into what shouldn't be.
+Simple yet challenging combat with a unique set of weaponry.
+Other characters that draw you into the world; sometimes making you laugh out loud and sometimes jump out of your seat.
+Two additional episodes to complete after the game that tie the story up nicely.

reviewText: This is one of the most atmospheric and interesting survival horror games I've played. It features a really nice fractured narrative, and the torchlight game mechanic works very well indeed. There's a couple of jump scares in there, but for the most part it relies on a deeply unsettling atmosphere to pull you in. And it works well. Graphically the game looks beautiful, even though it's getting on a bit now, and the episodic format allows you to pace your play. Each episode takes around two hors to complete, and there's six episodes (plus two more via DLC). The sound works well, the musical score is superb, and it features a number of great songs by Poets of the Fall, as well as various other artists new and old. I really can't recommend this game enough. Go and buy it.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
If you love kinds of mystery, you should find this interesting.

I will be spoiler free as much as I can.

::: Story :::
The story is a bit hard to get a hang of, I was confused until I was in the middle of the story, where everything started to reveal themselves. Nice story with twists here and there, and keep me wanting to see more till the end. However, I personally think that it shouldn't end where it is, just a little bit further would be nice !

::: Visual and FX :::
The game looks nice indeed, you can play as vanilla or enhance it with tool of your choice, sweetfx for example. One thing to look for is that the game use a lot of light FX, i mean, tons of them. (as the game concept is based around the light and the dark) If you have problem with dynamic lighting fx, feeling dizzy from looking at them, you might not enjoy the game much.

::: Gameplay :::
The overall gameplay is okay, the unique combat system, light the darkness then blow it away, is fresh enough to be enjoyable. however, I was expecting that it would be more of the adventure, but instead, it is more action-oriented game. I don't mean that it is bad, but the game will throw enemies at you along your journey to the level that it losts its charm as mystery-themed game.

Most encounters give you choices, to fight or to run. You can blast everything in your path with whatever at your disposal (tools, weapons, or even world's interactive objects), or avoid the encounter (if it isn't forced you to fight in the story), you can perform a timed-dodge, or even knock enemies off balance to get away from harms. The game utilized checkpoint system, when you reach it, the pursuers will be disappeared, and believe me, you will strive to get to it than stay and fight (especially in nightmare difficulty on your 2nd playthrough).

Encounters are well-designed, though they lack of visual variations (you will see them again and again). Almost all of them can be staggered, which will give you some breathing room for whatever reason. They will surprise you from time to time (on your first playthrough).

Your first playthrough will be a good experience, but on your 2nd or 3rd one on Nightmare difficulty, which you will be forced to play if you are intended to 100% the game, will become quite a task to finish, if you are the go-loud type. The achievements can be annoying (collect 100 of easily missed bottles), refering to the guide can help, a lot. It is fortunate that the game is in episodes, and can be replayed later.

The control is responsive and is good enough to allow you to face multiple enemies at once without too much troubles, although sometimes it is too fast XD.

::: Overall :::
The game is good. The designs match the concepts, however, they seems to think that more actions are better for this kind of games, but really, they are too much. It play nicely from the beginning to the end. I recommend this for a single playthough, as it lacks of dynamic elements, making the game predictable. 2nd or 3rd playthough will be more like archievement runs.

reviewText:
REVIEW: ALAN WAKE

(Main game only: DLC reviews to come separately, later)

I’m both an avid reader and a struggling writer. So to find a video game that looks at the perils and pitfalls of writing, albeit ensconced in a horror game, I decided to give it a shot. Ironically enough, I had read a novelization of Alan Wake long before I even got Steam. But how would experiencing the game go?

Bright Falls, an isolated town somewhere in Washington State. It seems like the perfect getaway for accomplished writer Alan Wake, who is trying to get away from his increasingly turbulent lifestyle, and have a quiet holiday with his wife Alice at a cabin. But after an argument, Alice disappears, and after trying to save her from a lake, Alan wakes up, to find that a week has passed, a week he has no memory of, and that people are being turned into beings wreathed in darkness, the Taken. What really happened to Alice? What does it have to do with obscure writer Thomas Zane? And is Alan imagining these events, or are they part of a darker plot to turn his writings into reality? With few people to trust, Alan must deal with sceptical authorities and ancient entities in order to save Alice…

One thing that I definitely enjoyed in Alan Wake more than anything else was the story. Even after reading the novelization, it felt like I came to it fresh and new. In fact, the TV-like ‘episodic’ format actually helps with the atmosphere, given that Twin Peaks was an influence. Of course, one of the biggest influences (and frequently acknowledged) is that of Stephen King. I’m reminded of Bag of Bones in particular. The atmosphere of the game is not unlike a more action-oriented version of Silent Hill, albeit with not as much psychological unease.

Graphics are one of the complaints I do have about the game. Not because they are bad: for the most part, they’re pretty damned good. But on my computer, low frame-rate, especially during some of the more intense combat systems, plagues the game regularly, and I was lucky to be able to defeat some enemies partly because of that frustrating frame rate. This suggests that using standard onboard chips for this game isn’t a good idea, even with the graphics at a low setting. Get a graphics card if you don’t want the frustrating frame-rate. However, the graphics themselves, as I mentioned, are beautiful, my only big complaint being the design and animation of Dr Hartman. For a character who is meant to be a smug and manipulative git, his facial expressions frequently make him look like he’s taken too many happy pills, and whatever threat he has as an antagonist is lessened significantly.

Sound-wise, I enjoyed the voice acting fairly well. It does well for what this game is, and the voice processing for the Taken is actually quite eerie and frightening, even if it does sound at times like a Cyberman’s voice from Doctor Who. Music, well, there’s plenty of good pieces, and there’s some interesting selections for the end credits for each episode. But I think the musical sting used whenever a Taken is within attacking range gets old real quick, and that it wouldn’t have hurt to have multiple stings to vary it somewhat.

Gameplay-wise, it seems to be the usual bit of action-shooter gameplay that horror games tend to be about nowadays. The combination of using a flashlight to render the Taken vulnerable and then shooting them is a novel one, but does wear a little, though using a flaregun and flashbangs as deadly weapons against the light-fearing creatures is enjoyable. But the camera controls for the mouse are too sensitive, even with the sensitivity turned down. The collectables do make it worthwhile, including reading manuscript pages that add to the backstory of the game, watching short episodes of a Twilight Zone-like TV show, and listening to radio shows that give some background.

Overall, Alan Wake is a pretty damn good game, hampered only by its incompatibility with some machines, and a number of other small flaws. Fans of Stephen King, David Lynch, or Silent Hill should give it a whirl.

RATING: ****

reviewText: I am not a fan of horror, but this game scratches an itch very few games do. It scratches a certain itch that usually comes with very well done psychological thriller movies, but it's stronger than that because of the nature of how games work. Being directly involved with the story of Alan Wake really creates a tension unlike any other. The way it uses suspense to create this tension is great, and while there are a few jumpscares in this game, that is not where the horror comes from. You'll find your heart rate beating at the times when you are alone, walking through a forest trail as the fog starts to creep in, politely letting you know that you are no longer safe.\n\nThe story is also fantastic and the way it pans out at the end will keep you thinking about it for weeks, maybe even years. I originally played this game when it first came out on the Xbox 360, and ever since then I think about this game regularly and recommend it at any chance I get, like now. And after a good few years without playing it I felt the need to go back an experience this once again to truly see if it holds up well now as it does in my memory. It definitely holds up, that is except the facial animations in the cutscenes. Those haven't aged too well, especially with the pixelated, low resolution that they are on. However, what truly makes this game special, the atmosphere, the story, the sense of a journey, and just the general horror of it all... Those have definitely held up. And other than P.T. on the PS4 Store (which uses atmosphere in a similar way, although P.T. is more jumpscare centred than AW), nothing has even came close to replicating this kind of horror game since, which is a shame because I really like this kind of horror, even though I'm not a fan of the overall genre across all mediums, I really hope Alan Wake gets a true sequel some day or at the very least a very good spiritual successor done in the same vein as this game.

reviewText:
What started off as an impulse purchase became (without exaggeration) one of the most amazing gaming experiences in my life. Alan Wake is an outstanding game that mixes elements of psychological horror, thriller and and dark fantasy. Bright Falls are a perfect setting for the story of a dark, somewhat magical, entity going after the protagonist. It also features a lot of meta-elements (like the manuscript pages the protagonist finds scattered throughout the game, which give us insight into the plot and, in some cases, the events that are about to occur or which we do not see on-screen).

As for the gaming aspect: although some might find the combat monotonous, I personally always get the cold shiver each time Alan steps into a secluded part of the forest that's bound to hide malavolent lurkers. The limited amunnition and the character's poor stamina add an extra spice to the gameplay, but the developers made sure that you are able to get to the next chekpoint even with no bullets left in the barrel (alhough it's much harder). The fights are not quite scary nor horror, as the game even hints that there are enemies inbound, but is definitely adrenaline packed and fun.

The story is well-crafted, and the narration helps bring it to life. The entire plot is a huge nod to Stephen King and a myriad of other contemporary horror writers. There are a lot of references to The Shining
recommended: Poltergeist" and "Lost" scattered throughout the game. The dialogues are neither superficial nor superflous

reviewText:
HEY GUYS!  I'm just like Stephen King and Dean Koontz!  I mean, I write scary stories, I like to live in small quirky towns in the middle of BFE North East, and creepy ♥♥♥♥ happens to me all the time!  See, just like Stephen King and Dean Koontz!

Don't get me wrong, Alan Wake's all right.  He's just a little heavy on the reference dropping.  If you can get past that, you can get your self a Stephen Koontz esque story that's a bit creepy and overall pretty interesting.  There's nothing too exciting here mechanics wise (KINDA LIKE A DEAN KOONTZ NOVEL AMIRITE?) but let's face it; you're really just here for the story and movie like experience.

In small doses, the 'haha, i'm a troubled writer' schtick doesn't get too thick.  Thankfully, it's laid out in a episodic format which means it's in nice digestible chunks.  Something that Stephen King's novels could use sometimes.  Play this one episode at a time, with your lights off, and it'll be more satisfying than how the Dark Tower played out!

reviewText:
REVIEW: ALAN WAKE

(Main game only: DLC reviews to come separately, later)

I’m both an avid reader and a struggling writer. So to find a video game that looks at the perils and pitfalls of writing, albeit ensconced in a horror game, I decided to give it a shot. Ironically enough, I had read a novelization of Alan Wake long before I even got Steam. But how would experiencing the game go?

Bright Falls, an isolated town somewhere in Washington State. It seems like the perfect getaway for accomplished writer Alan Wake, who is trying to get away from his increasingly turbulent lifestyle, and have a quiet holiday with his wife Alice at a cabin. But after an argument, Alice disappears, and after trying to save her from a lake, Alan wakes up, to find that a week has passed, a week he has no memory of, and that people are being turned into beings wreathed in darkness, the Taken. What really happened to Alice? What does it have to do with obscure writer Thomas Zane? And is Alan imagining these events, or are they part of a darker plot to turn his writings into reality? With few people to trust, Alan must deal with sceptical authorities and ancient entities in order to save Alice…

One thing that I definitely enjoyed in Alan Wake more than anything else was the story. Even after reading the novelization, it felt like I came to it fresh and new. In fact, the TV-like ‘episodic’ format actually helps with the atmosphere, given that Twin Peaks was an influence. Of course, one of the biggest influences (and frequently acknowledged) is that of Stephen King. I’m reminded of Bag of Bones in particular. The atmosphere of the game is not unlike a more action-oriented version of Silent Hill, albeit with not as much psychological unease.

Graphics are one of the complaints I do have about the game. Not because they are bad: for the most part, they’re pretty damned good. But on my computer, low frame-rate, especially during some of the more intense combat systems, plagues the game regularly, and I was lucky to be able to defeat some enemies partly because of that frustrating frame rate. This suggests that using standard onboard chips for this game isn’t a good idea, even with the graphics at a low setting. Get a graphics card if you don’t want the frustrating frame-rate. However, the graphics themselves, as I mentioned, are beautiful, my only big complaint being the design and animation of Dr Hartman. For a character who is meant to be a smug and manipulative git, his facial expressions frequently make him look like he’s taken too many happy pills, and whatever threat he has as an antagonist is lessened significantly.

Sound-wise, I enjoyed the voice acting fairly well. It does well for what this game is, and the voice processing for the Taken is actually quite eerie and frightening, even if it does sound at times like a Cyberman’s voice from Doctor Who. Music, well, there’s plenty of good pieces, and there’s some interesting selections for the end credits for each episode. But I think the musical sting used whenever a Taken is within attacking range gets old real quick, and that it wouldn’t have hurt to have multiple stings to vary it somewhat.

Gameplay-wise, it seems to be the usual bit of action-shooter gameplay that horror games tend to be about nowadays. The combination of using a flashlight to render the Taken vulnerable and then shooting them is a novel one, but does wear a little, though using a flaregun and flashbangs as deadly weapons against the light-fearing creatures is enjoyable. But the camera controls for the mouse are too sensitive, even with the sensitivity turned down. The collectables do make it worthwhile, including reading manuscript pages that add to the backstory of the game, watching short episodes of a Twilight Zone-like TV show, and listening to radio shows that give some background.

Overall, Alan Wake is a pretty damn good game, hampered only by its incompatibility with some machines, and a number of other small flaws. Fans of Stephen King, David Lynch, or Silent Hill should give it a whirl.

RATING: ****

reviewText: Борьба света против тьмы... в прямом смысле. Алан Уэйк, успешный писатель, отправляется в отпуск в Брайт Фоллс со своей женой. В ту же ночь, по стечении обстоятельств, его жена оказывается похищена. Но история оказывается не так проста, каждую ночь, город наполняет настоящая тьма, поглощая людей и управляя ими! На пути по спасению жены, лучшим другом Алана (не считая Барри) станет его карманный фонарик. Отныне, это не просто источник света, но и оружие! Любой враг, находящийся в темноте, попросту неуязвим, посему, прежде чем нажать на курок, вам предстоит выбить" из врага всю темную силу мощным потоком света! Уникальный геймплей и захватывающая история."

reviewText:
Alan Wake: a unique, horror themed casual-action game.Alan Wake is a self-aware, chapter based, mainly combat-driven action game that anyone could get into. Personally I recommend that you play on easy, because if there is one downside to the game, it's that the combat system wears you down after the whole experience. There's also a difficulty spike right at the mine, but it's not too bad. The game isn't scary, but does have a light v. dark sort of theme.
It's also kid-friendly, for the most part.

Alan Wake's story reminds me of a Steven King novel (Wake himself makes the comparison). A writer comes to an old small-town cabin to get away from the fame and fortune. He runs into some issues, and his wife (who fears the dark) is captured by some darkness-something-or-another. It's pretty cool and non-complex, but mysterious enough to remain intriguing.
The entire game is narrated by Alan Wake, in the form of a novel, while you traverse the dark countryside.

Combat is simple. Fight the nightmare-men by getting rid of their (as I call them) darkness shields" then shooting them. Their darkness shields are shown by a circle of lense flare when you aim your flashlight at them. Shoot them with either the revolver or shotgun to kill them. Alternatively
date:
flare guns do both simultaneously. Flares and flashbangs clear crowds.
Fight men from your dreams (and people you have met) through a story with cool bits of radio and TV clips.

The story is good
recommended: but unfortunately to prevent the game from being a 5 hour experience
hoursPlayed: there's a lot of repetitive combat. Some people really like it
voteText: but in my opinion it could have been a bit shorter."

reviewText:
TL;DR Great atmosphere, fluid gameplay, well made storyline (alot of extra info given through world items) and good difficulty.

Alan Wake is the protagonist of his own story, trapped inside the pages he writes when he blacks out. At the start, you arrive in Bright Falls to relax and get some inspiration for your next book ''Departure'', when a bunch of weird things happen. People posessed by darkness and evil appear to try and end Alan's life, and he must fight through it to save his wife.

The game overral has a great atmosphere, giving you a jist of the story through dialogue and giving you the rest through hidden pages/TV's/Radios. It's dark, and you fend off enemies with your greatest weapon: LIGHT! (oh and guns too). The game is very well written and narrated as it's done by Alan himself (they really went full out by modeling a character from a real guy). The game also has a bunch of small jumpscares scattered throughout the game in the form of 2 second cutscenes with lound noises, but I guess you get used to it. The gameplay part is fun and Wake moves fluidly through Bright Falls.

Overall, I would definitly recommend this to any fan of good storytelling and mystery. It was the best(or close to) from it's genre in the Xbox 360 Generation.

reviewText: Борьба света против тьмы... в прямом смысле. Алан Уэйк, успешный писатель, отправляется в отпуск в Брайт Фоллс со своей женой. В ту же ночь, по стечении обстоятельств, его жена оказывается похищена. Но история оказывается не так проста, каждую ночь, город наполняет настоящая тьма, поглощая людей и управляя ими! На пути по спасению жены, лучшим другом Алана (не считая Барри) станет его карманный фонарик. Отныне, это не просто источник света, но и оружие! Любой враг, находящийся в темноте, попросту неуязвим, посему, прежде чем нажать на курок, вам предстоит выбить" из врага всю темную силу мощным потоком света! Уникальный геймплей и захватывающая история."

reviewText: Stephen King once wrote that “Nightmares exist outside of logic, and there’s little fun to be had in explanations; they’re antithetical to the poetry of fear.” In a horror story, the victim keeps asking Why?" But there can be no explanation
date: and there shouldn’t be one. The unanswered mystery is what stays with us the longest
recommended: and it’s what we’ll remember in the end. My name is Alan Wake. I’m a writer."

reviewText:
Simply one of the best horror/survival/action/adventure games I've played since Silent Hill 2.  You play the role of Alan Wake, an author on a vacation with his wife to unwind in a small lakeside town.  What follows is a rollercoaster ride of confusion, realization, depression, and redemption.
+Beautiful and surreal loactions that breath new life into what shouldn't be.
+Simple yet challenging combat with a unique set of weaponry.
+Other characters that draw you into the world; sometimes making you laugh out loud and sometimes jump out of your seat.
+Two additional episodes to complete after the game that tie the story up nicely.

reviewText:
This game is probably one of the most cleverly written games that I have ever played. I didn't have high expectations for this game and just assumed originally that it would follow some typical horror game tropes and just be something I played through only because I bought it.

As the story progresses things become far more complex and by the ending there are a wealth of questions that need to be anwered and several possibilities of what is actually happening in this world.

Unfortunately, we probably won't ever get much beyond American Nightmare so we may unfortunately never finish this possibly incredible storyline.

reviewText:
First of, the story is fantastic, it's just like playing a great book; and the more you play the more you fall in love with it. Gameplay, however, can get pretty repetitive, and you might grow tired of it during long sessions. It kept me on the edge of my seat for a good couple of hours; but near the end I simply became extremely tired of the gameplay, and would've stopped playing if it weren't for the cutscenes that kept me going.

I would absolutely recommend this game to someone who loves thriller/horror games. Just the story alone makes me want recommend it, no questions asked. Protip: play in intervals. Play one episode, and then put the controller down for a day or two, and then continue (just like some books).

reviewText:
There is something about this game that just feels like you are playing a Steven King book.

Things I liked:
+The action is fun -- The combat is pretty simple but they do a lot to mix up the combat. You feel fragile, so it's tense, but the enemies aren't insurmountable either, so it's a very nice balance.

+The atmosphere is amazing. -- As mentioned you actually feel like you are a character within some kind of horror book. I don't know how they did it, but it's spot on.

Things I didn't like:
-The game is a little too long to not add new elements or progression -- The game is long because the story is long, so that part isn't bad. It would have made the gameplay grow a little less stale towards the end if they had maybe incorporated some minor progression system or a couple extra weapons just to switch things up as you are tying it all together.

All in all, must check this game out, it's fantastic.
